{"code":1,"isDone":false,"toInsertArticleList":[{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","title":"The most anticipated new TV shows premiering in September","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/most-anticipated-new-shows-of-september-ratched-raised-by-wolves-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d04d77ffa48002894d1b7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"ratched netflix\" height=\"1340\" width=\"2066\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Sarah Paulson in &#34;Ratched&#34;\n<p class=\"copyright\">Netflix</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>Every month, TV Time provides Business Insider with the five most anticipated new TV shows.</li><li>September includes Netflix's \"Ratched\" and HBO Max's \"Raised By Wolves.\"</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\" data-uri=\"f0e80ded5d35b2778c5da3bdda2e6898\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>Ryan Murphy is back with another Netflix series.</p><p>The superstar producer has delivered \"The Politician\" and \"Hollywood\" to disappointing critical reception after striking a lucrative deal with the streaming giant in 2018. His next project, \"Ratched,\" is a prequel to the Oscar-winning movie \"One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest,\" centered on Sarah Paulson's troubling Nurse Ratched, originally played by Louise Fletcher.</p><p>Every month, Business Insider runs down the five most anticipated new shows using data from television-tracking app&#160;<a href=\"https://www.tvtime.com/en\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"613c6af480c32172e1d1e22964325b00\">TV Time</a>, derived from its millions of users around the world who use the app to track and react to what they're watching.</p><p>September also sees the debut of the mysterious sci-fi series \"Raised By Wolves,\" from \"Alien\" and \"Gladiator\" director Ridley Scott. It premieres September 20 on HBO Max, but has already received positive reviews and has an 82% critic score on Rotten Tomatoes.</p><section data-slideshow-intro-content=\"\"><section data-slideshow-intro-content=\"\"><section data-slideshow-intro-content=\"\"><section data-slideshow-intro-content=\"\"><section data-slideshow-intro-content=\"\"><p><strong>Below are the five most anticipated new shows of September:</strong></p></section></section></section></section></section>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\t5. \"Utopia\" — Amazon Prime Video, September 25\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d089f60bf1f0028079721?format=jpeg\" alt=\"utopia prime video\" height=\"1314\" width=\"2018\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Prime Video</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dFSKBllxRIw\"><strong>Description</strong></a>: \"When the conspiracy in the elusive comic Utopia is real, a group of young fans come together to embark on a high-stakes twisted adventure to use what they uncover to save themselves, each other, and ultimately humanity. Starring John Cusack, Rainn Wilson, and Sasha Lane.\"</p>\n\t4. \"We Are Who We Are\" — HBO, September 14\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d09657ffa48002894d1d7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"we are who we are hbo\" height=\"1248\" width=\"1890\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">HBO</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u6VAQ6LdnKs\"><strong>Description</strong></a>: \"From Luca Guadagnino, the director of Call Me By Your Name, We Are Who We Are follows a group of teens growing up on an American Army base outside of Venice, Italy struggling to find their own identities as they move into young-adulthood. \"</p>\n\t3. \"The Third Day\" — HBO, September 14\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d0ac17ffa48002894d1dc?format=jpeg\" alt=\"the third day hbo\" height=\"1342\" width=\"1974\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">HBO/Sky Atlantic UK</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T43V6z9wYyE\"><strong>Description</strong></a>: \"Created by Dennis Kelly and Felix Barrett, The Third Day is told over the first three episodes. 'Summer' follows Sam, a man drawn to a mysterious Island off the British coast, who encounters a group of islanders set on preserving their traditions at any cost. 'Winter' unfolds over the latter three episodes as Helen, a strong-willed outsider who comes to the island seeking answers, but whose arrival precipitates a fractious battle to decide its fate. The limited series stars Jude Law, Naomie Harris, Katherine Waterston, Emily Watson, and Paddy Considine.\"</p>\n\t2. \"Raised By Wolves\" — HBO Max, September 20\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d0cb660bf1f0028079738?format=jpeg\" alt=\"raised by wolves\" height=\"1180\" width=\"2010\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">HBO Max</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rE92bDAlPXI\"><strong>Description</strong></a>: \"Two androids are tasked with raising human children on a mysterious virgin planet. As the burgeoning colony of humans threatens to be torn apart by religious differences, the androids learn that controlling the beliefs of humans is a treacherous and difficult task.\"</p>\n\t1. \"Ratched\" — Netflix, September 3\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d0ce67ffa48002894d1eb?format=jpeg\" alt=\"ratched netflix\" height=\"1284\" width=\"1712\" creator of American Horror Story, witness the origin of one of the world's most iconic characters, Nurse Ratched.\"</p>\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 1@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-22-02-465_f39a212a2fe64d1a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598894512872},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","title":"United Airlines nixes (most) change fees — but you'll still have to pay the difference in airfare","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/united-airlines-ends-most-ticket-change-fees-not-basic-economy-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e6aa061e4f9fe439102a587?format=jpeg\" alt=\"A passenger, standing at a ticket counter of U.S. carrier United Airlines, wears a protective mask at Frankfurt Airport, Germany, March 12, 2020.   REUTERS/Ralph Orlowski\" height=\"3020\" width=\"4414\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Passenger, standing at a ticket counter of U.S. carrier United Airlines, wears a protective mask at Frankfurt Airport\n<p class=\"copyright\">Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>United Airlines announced this week that it's permanently ending most ticket-change fees.&#160;</li><li>A fee for changing a basic economy ticket will remain.</li><li>The new policy takes effect January 1.</li><li>United, like its peers, is struggling to attract as many passengers as possible in the face of steep cuts as it tries to remain solvent amid the coronavirus pandemic.</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>Much-maligned change fees will be no more on most United Airlines flights starting next year.</p><p>The carrier said Sunday that it will eliminate the $200 surcharge on all standard economy and premium tickets as it seeks to entice as many returning passengers as possible despite travel numbers that remain deeply depressed amid the coronavirus pandemic.</p><p>Basic economy tickets will still be subject to the fees, and passengers will have to pay any difference in fare, which could be steep if a change is made near the departure date. There's no limit on how many times a flight can be changed, and the new policy takes effect January 1.</p><p>\"When we hear from customers about where we can improve, getting rid of this fee is often the top request,\" CEO Scott Kirby <a href=\"https://hub.united.com/2020-08-30-united-airlines-permanently-eliminates-change-fees-2647406401.html\">said in a press release. </a></p><p>Overall passenger traffic in the US is slowly starting to increase, according to <a href=\"https://www.tsa.gov/coronavirus/passenger-throughput\">numbers released by the Transportation Security Administration</a>, but checkpoint counts remained at less than 30% of the prior year's numbers during August. Worldwide, capacity is down about 40%, according to estimates from Stifel analysts.</p><p>That's meant steep cuts at United &#8212; and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/american-airlines-furloughs-layoffs-coronavirus-2020-8\">virtually</a> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/delta-air-lines-furlough-pilots-layoff-coronavirus-2020-8\">all</a> of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-travel-industry-job-losses-197-million-wttc-2020-8\">its</a> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/southwest-airlines-cares-act-loan-decline-demand-2020-8\">competitors</a> &#8212; in order to stay alive after the initial round of economic stimulus passed by US lawmakers in March. United said <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/united-airlines-to-cut-2850-pilot-jobs-without-more-us-government-aid-2020-8\">last week it plans to furlough 2,850 pilots this year</a>, or about 21% of its total pilot jobs, without further government intervention. Up to 36,000 jobs could be at risk, the airline previously said.</p><p>Congress and the White House appear to remain at an impasse over further aid measures after a month of debate. Unemployment and the pandemic, meanwhile, show no signs of slowing anytime soon. The US <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/coronavirus-us-cases.html\">reported 33,452 new cases on Sunday</a>, while average daily case counts have fallen 18% in recent weeks.</p><p>July and August are usually the busiest time of year for airlines, thanks to a summer travel rush. Yet traffic is only barely above April lows, according to estimates from UBS. Business travel, long a boon for airlines' bottom lines, doesn't appear to be returning soon either.</p><p>In order to break even financially, United has said it needs to be flying at about half capacity.</p><p>\"We believe that when demand returns, based on the work the entire United team has accomplished in cutting costs to respond to the crisis, we will be in the best position to reach cash burn breakeven, which we expect will be in an environment where demand and capacity are down around 50%,\" CFO Gerry Laderman said in July.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/dS3cRrUhQKc\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 31 Aug 2020 15:12:58 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f4d05f560bf1f002807970c?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"a12d7d63c04534a4f7fa3260c8e90f4d","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn60@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-21-56-864_e9a4534488c5e64c.webp","destWidth":4025,"destHeight":3018,"sourceBytes":195454,"destBytes":195454,"author":"grapier@businessinsider.com (Graham Rapier)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5e6aa061e4f9fe439102a587?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn87@2020_4/2020/08/31/17-22-06-045_8ddd7108d1270b06.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn51@2020_3/2020/08/31/17-22-14-421_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=dS3cRrUhQKc:YQDevX3HQZs:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn63@2020_2/2020/08/31/17-21-57-881_111626b335dd360d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=dS3cRrUhQKc:YQDevX3HQZs:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn12@2020_2/2020/08/31/17-22-13-816_46f169b4b2251f80.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn76@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-22-07-798_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=dS3cRrUhQKc:YQDevX3HQZs:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn32@2020_6/2020/08/31/17-21-59-646_897dbf7d29a0700a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/dS3cRrUhQKc":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn99@2020_4/2020/08/31/17-21-57-020_60028a23b014e69f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598894512832},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","title":"What pregnant women should know about the coronavirus","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-pregnant-women-should-know-about-the-coronavirus-2020-3","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e629ce1fee23d4f26318dd2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"pregnant women and coronavirus 4x3\" height=\"900\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Crystal Cox/Business Insider; Samantha Lee/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>Pregnant women are concerned and confused about what the <a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/category/wuhan-coronavirus\">novel coronavirus</a> might mean for them, their births, and their future children, as <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/china-virus-everything-we-know-deadly-2019-ncov-wuhan-spread-2020-1\">evidence and advice keeps changing</a>.&#160;</li><li>Pregnant women don't seem to be especially susceptible to the illness, but they may be at risk for more severe cases if they do acquire it.</li><li>It appears unlikely that the virus can transmit in utero, and unlikely but not impossible for it to be passed on in breastmilk.&#160;</li><li>But it is possible for infants to get COVID-19; most cases are mild or asymptomatic, but rarely, it can be serious.</li><li>Pregnant women should continue their prenatal appointments, take serious precautions to prevent contracting the virus, and seek mental-health support.&#160;</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>When <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-is-forcing-pregnant-women-to-rethink-birth-plans-2020-3\">Jen Judson</a> announced her second pregnancy in October 2019, she never imagined her mom wouldn't be there for the birth, her husband wouldn't be able to stay in the hospital room with her post-delivery, and that the months leading up to the late April birth would be riveted by anxieties related to a virus no one had heard of.&#160;</p><p>She worried about contracting the virus, being separated from her baby after the birth, running out of diapers, and following medical advice that could later be overturned.&#160;&#160;</p><p>\"I'm feeling less in control, more worried, as new data comes in about infected infants and pregnant women, and more worried about the state of our world and country when the baby is born,\" Judson told Business Insider in March.&#160;</p><p>Lauren McCauley, who's due in early fall, shared similar anxieties. \"I feel like we don't know enough about this virus; however, what we do know seems to worsen daily,\" she told Business Insider. \"One moment they are saying pregnant women should be OK, then a week later, the UK is recommending pregnant women stay home for three months.\"&#160;</p><p>Researchers are doctors are still learning exactly how COVID-19, the disease the coronavirus causes, affects pregnant women and their future babies. Pregnant women should continue their prenatal appointments, take precautions to protect themselves, and seek support. Here's what else research and experts suggest as of late June.&#160;</p><h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5da47f43cc4a0a3513408b05?format=jpeg\" alt=\"pregnant woman OB-GYN\" height=\"2000\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Teresa Crawford</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></h2><h2>Pregnant women don't seem especially susceptible to the illness, but racial disparities persist</h2><p>Pregnant women are at greater risk of severe morbidity and mortality from other respiratory infections like the flu, so they \"should be considered an <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/health-conditions-that-increase-risk-of-severe-coronavirus-infection-2020-3\">at-risk population for COVID-19</a>,\" according to the <a href=\"https://www.acog.org/clinical/clinical-guidance/practice-advisory/articles/2020/03/novel-coronavirus-2019\">American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists</a>.</p><p>Still, they don't seem be especially susceptible to COVID-19 the way age or conditions like lung or heart disease does, Dr. Jane van Dis, an OB-GYN who serves as medical director at the telemedicine network <a href=\"https://www.mavenclinic.com/\">Maven</a>, told Business Insider.&#160;</p><p>\"While I think pregnant women should practice every degree of social distancing that they can because that is just smart, I don't think pregnant women should feel a sense of panic,\" she said. \"We're just not seeing the data to show that the virus is attacking their immune system in the same way as someone, say, over the age of 70.\"</p><p>There is a racial disparity, however, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/cdc-pregnant-women-increased-risk-for-severe-coronavirus-cases-hospitalization-2020-6\">with an analysis out of the CDC</a> finding that Black and Hispanic pregnant women seem to be disproportionately affected by COVID-19.&#160;&#160;</p><p>All women and their families should do what they can to protect themselves from the illness.&#160;</p><p>That means taking social distancing seriously (van Dis recommends pregnant women have someone else get their groceries, for instance), <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-prevent-wuhan-coronavirus-hygiene-hand-washing-2020-2\">practicing excellent hygiene</a>, and avoiding anyone who seems sick.</p><p>Women should continue their prenatal visits but may consider making some virtual, said van Dis, whose platform digitally connects women to providers including maternal-fetal medicine specialists, midwives, doulas, mental-health providers, lactation consultants and more.&#160;</p><h2>If pregnant women do get COVID-19, they may be more likely to be hospitalized&#160;</h2><p>If pregnant women do get the virus, they may be at increased risk for hospitalization, ICU admission, and mechanical ventilation, according to the largest report of its type, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/cdc-pregnant-women-increased-risk-for-severe-coronavirus-cases-hospitalization-2020-6\">the same one out of the CDC June 25</a>.</p><p>It was unclear, however, if these hospitalizations were related to COVID-19 or pregnancy, labor, and delivery, so the findings should be interpreted cautiously. And, it was still rare for pregnant women to need serious care, with 1.5% admitted to the ICU and 0.5% put on ventilators.&#160;</p><p>This reflects an earlier investigation of 147 pregnant women in China who either had or were suspected to have COVID-19. It found that only 8% had severe cases and 1% had critical cases.&#160;</p><p>Women of color seem again to be more susceptible to severe illness, with&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/half-pregnant-women-in-uk-coronavirus-black-ethnic-minorities-2020-6\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\">another study out of the UK</a> finding more than half of pregnant women who were admitted to the hospital with COVID-19 were Black or from other minority ethnic groups.&#160;</p><p>Marian Knight, the study's lead, previously told Insider more qualitative research involving talking to women about their experiences is \"urgently needed\" to help understand what puts pregnant women of color at such risk for COVID-19.&#160;</p><h2>There is some evidence that pregnant women with COVID-19 could pass it to their babies in utero&#160;</h2><p>Prior to March 26, research suggested pregnant women with COVID-19 could not pass on the disease in utero.&#160;</p><p>A Lancet <a href=\"https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0140673620303603\">study</a> of nine pregnant women in Wuhan who had COVID-19, for one, found their babies tested negative. There was no evidence of the virus in breast milk, amniotic fluid, or cord blood, either.&#160;</p><p>And, of the 34 cases of babies born to women with COVID-19 that were discussed in a March 12 <a href=\"https://emergency.cdc.gov/coca/calls/2020/callinfo_031220.asp\">CDC seminar</a> for medical professionals, none tested positive for the illness.&#160;</p><p>But <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/pregnant-women-coronavirus-may-pass-covid-19-in-utero-2020-3\">a trio of studies out March 26</a> brought those conclusions into question, in part by showing how some babies still tested positive for COVID-19 when strict prevention measures were taken after birth.</p><p>In two of the studies, researchers found evidence of a certain antibody in some of the babies' blood with only one likely explanation: The coronavirus crossed through the placenta and prompted them to appear.</p><p>\"These two papers give evidence that COVID-19 can likely be vertically transmitted from a mother to her fetus,\" Dr. Jessica Madden, a pediatrician and neonatologist who serves as medical director of <a href=\"https://aeroflowbreastpumps.com/\">Aeroflow Breastpumps</a>, told Business Insider.&#160;</p><p>One <a href=\"https://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/wk/inf/2020/00000039/00000009/art00011\">case report</a> out July 7 also described a pre-term infant who tested positive for the virus when they were two days old.&#160;</p><p>Still, it seems most babies born to COVID-positive mothers don't get infected, thanks to strict hospital protocols. Of the 24 babies born to COVID-positive moms in Los Angeles County, for instance, none <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-live-updates-latest-news\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\">tested positive for the virus</a>.&#160;</p><p>Even <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/a-small-new-study-suggests-the-coronavirus-damages-the-placenta-2020-5?r=US&IR=TIR=T\">a small study</a> finding placental damage, presumably due to the virus, in pregnant women, none of their babies acquired the illness.&#160;</p><h2>Babies and infants can be infected, 90% of the time they're asymptomatic or have mild symptoms&#160;</h2><p>While babies and children seem to be less vulnerable to the virus than adults, they can acquire the infection, and in some cases, it can be serious.&#160;</p><p>In a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/some-children-develop-severe-infections-from-coronavirus-2020-3?r=US&IR=TIR=T\">study out March 17 of 2,000 kids in China who were diagnosed with</a> COVID-19, researchers found that infants have the highest risk of developing severe or critical infections. Just over 10% of all infants in the study ended up in a severe condition, compared to 7% of kids aged one to five years old, 4% of six- to 10-year-olds, 4% of 11- to 15-year-olds, and 3% of older teenagers.</p><p>However, 90% of the children were either asymptomatic or had mild or moderate COVID-19 symptoms, like fever, fatigue, sore throat, cough, or shortness of breath.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ce5a430df29c80f662e8033?format=jpeg\" alt=\"breast pump\" height=\"1415\" width=\"2119\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2>Delivering with COVID-19 can make other complications more likely, but babies can still be breastfed&#160;</h2><p>Like any respiratory illness, COVID-19 can make it more likely for pregnant women to have complications,&#160;namely preterm birth, according to the CDC.</p><p>Another <a href=\"http://tp.amegroups.com/article/view/35919/28274\">study</a> in the journal Translational Pediatrics of 10 Chinese newborns whose moms have COVID-19 found six developed shortness of breath, two had fever, two had abnormal platelets and liver function tests, and one experienced vomiting. One went into septic shock and died, Madden&#160;<a href=\"https://www.novamaemd.com/single-post/2020/03/07/What-do-we-know-about-COVID-19-and-newborns\">summarizes on her blog</a>.&#160;</p><p>But, like much of the research on the topic, the sample size was small and there's no way to know if those complications were caused by COVID-19 or other factors, or some combination.&#160;</p><p>Still, Madden wrote, pregnant women with COVID-19 should plan to give birth in a hospital, where they must follow CDC recommendations for managing them and their newborns to reduce the risk of transmission after birth. That may mean&#160;putting moms and their babies in separate isolation rooms, or keeping mom and newborn six feet apart, Madden said.&#160;</p><p>\"Each hospital is following the CDC's guidelines based on their own local resources and hospital censuses,\" she said.&#160;</p><p>After delivery, as of June 25 <a href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/need-extra-precautions/pregnancy-breastfeeding.html\">the CDC still recommended</a> pregnant women with COVID-19 breastfeed because there's no proof that the virus can pass through breastmilk, though there is <a href=\"https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2769825\">some evidence</a> that the substance can carry the virus's RNA.&#160;</p><p>New moms with the virus should wear a mask, though, and naturally, wash their hands thoroughly beforehand.&#160;</p><p>\"If a woman wants to take extra precaution, think about pumping milk and then having someone else feed the baby,\" van Dis said.&#160;</p><h2>Seek help and support</h2><p>It's true that there's a lot experts don't know about how the novel coronavirus affects pregnant women and their babies, and it's natural to feel anxious about the unknown.</p><p>Pregnant women and new moms, who are already vulnerable to depression and anxiety, are experiencing remarkably high rates &#8212; 41% and 72% respectively &#8212; of those symptoms now, <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/coronavirus-linked-high-rates-depression-anxiety-pregnant-women-new-moms-2020-6\">one report showed</a>.&#160;</p><p>Manage the anxiety but set parameters around how much you read about or watch news about the issue, <a href=\"http://www.juliepike.com/\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\">Julie Pike</a>, a clinical psychologist in Chapel Hill, North Carolina, who specializes in anxiety disorders,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-cope-with-coronavirus-covid-19-anxiety-psychologist-2020-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\">previously told Insider</a>.&#160;</p><p>Too much exposure, especially from sketchy sources, can make consumers overestimate threat and underestimate their coping abilities, which is a&#160;<a href=\"https://www.insider.com/gisele-buendchen-adopted-healthy-lifestyle-overcome-anxiety-panic-attacks-2020-3\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\">recipe for anxiety</a>.&#160;</p><p>It's also important to reach out to others &#8212; mental health professionals, friends, support groups, or all of the above &#8212; for social support during such an isolating time, with <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/online-mental-health-resources-for-coronavirus-related-anxiety-stress-2020-3\">many different resources</a> available for virtual mental-health help.&#160;</p><p>\"There are going to be a lot of emotions, some of which are sadness, grief and the unknown,\" van Dis said. \"Just know that connecting with people who are there to support women is essential for mental health.\"&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/what-pregnant-women-should-know-about-the-coronavirus-2020-3'>Business 01:21:52","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","title":"Former White House chief of staff Mick Mulvaney to open hedge fund focused on financial stocks","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/mick-mulvaney-hedge-fund-former-chief-staff-financial-stocks-washington-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d0cb87ffa48002894d1e8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Mick Mulvaney Donald Trump\" height=\"1500\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Acting White House Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mark Wilson/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul><li><strong>Former White House chief of staff Mick Mulvaney plans to launch a hedge fund focused on financial-sector stocks.</strong></li><li><strong>The firm, named Exegis Capital, will leverage Mulvaney's experience in government to find opportunities linked to legislation and regulation, he said in an appearance on S&#38;P Global's \"<a href=\"https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/veteran-investor-mick-mulvaney-launching-financial-stock-focused-fund-60055860\">Street Talk</a>\" podcast.</strong></li><li><strong>Investors \"like to think the market moves on fundamentals\" but policy out of Washington plays an increasingly important role, Mulvaney added.</strong></li><li><strong>Mulvaney, now serving as special envoy to Northern Ireland, aims to open the fund on January 1 with investing veteran Andrew Wessel.</strong></li><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestutm_source=msn.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_content=msn-slideshow&utm_campaign=bodyurl?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestts&#38;utm_medium=ingest\">Visit the Business Insider homepage for more stories</a>.</strong></li></ul><hr ><p>Mick Mulvaney, former White House chief of staff, is starting a hedge fund aimed at leveraging his knowledge of financial industry regulation.</p><p>In an appearance on the \"<a href=\"https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/veteran-investor-mick-mulvaney-launching-financial-stock-focused-fund-60055860\">Street Talk</a>\" podcast hosted by S&#38;P Global Market Intelligence, Mulvaney said he's launching a fund with investing veteran Andrew Wessel. The firm, named Exegis Capital, will focus on financial-sector stocks with a combination of long and short positions.&#160;</p><p>Investors \"like to think the market moves on fundamentals\" but government policy is playing an increasingly large role in driving markets, the former chief of staff said.</p><p>\"Politics is going to be a very turbulent thing in the near future, and I think it creates opportunities for those who understand how Washington works,\" Mulvaney said.</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-investing-championship-strategy-matthew-caruso-contender-secret-to-return-2020-8\" data-analytics-position=\"1\" data-analytics-module=\"\">US Investing Championship hopeful Matthew Caruso landed a 382% return in the first half of 2020. He shares the unique twist he's putting on a classic trading strategy &#8212; and 3 stocks he's holding right now.</a></em></p><p>President Donald Trump appointed Mulvaney as special envoy to Northern Ireland in March after he served as chief of staff for more than a year. Former Representative Mark Meadows took Mulvaney's role in the White House. Mulvaney now serves as a special government employee and plans to continue in the role while founding Exegis, a source familiar with the matter told <a href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/2020/08/28/mick-mulvaney-hedge-fund-404643?nname=playbook&nid=0000014f-1646-d88f-a1cf-5f46b7bd0000&nrid=00000164-0375-dae3-ade4-4f7da1e00000&nlid=630318;nlid=630318\">Politico</a>.</p><p>The former chief of staff highlighted recent market rallies as backing up his argument that fundamentals now play second fiddle to Washington. Stimulus progress and positive coronavirus drug news have repeatedly pushed major equity indexes higher in recent weeks despite continued economic pain, he said.</p><p>That trend will surely continue, and those with experience in government will know how to best position themselves with respect to future legislation and regulation, Mulvaney added.</p><p>\"Not a lot of folks get it. Not a lot of folks understand, OK, this person has hired this staffer to run this subcommittee, what is that going to mean for what kinds of legislation you're seeing come out?\" he said.</p><p>Mulvaney and Wessel began raising capital for the fund about a month ago, Wessel said on the podcast. The two aim to open the fund on January 1, and will do so whether Trump or Vice President Joe Biden wins November's presidential election.</p><p>Other government players moved into the market recently as stocks rebounded from their virus-induced lows. Former House Speaker Paul Ryan is <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/paul-ryan-spac-chairman-blank-check-300-million-ipo-acquisition-2020-8-1029521755\">set to hop on the \"blank-check\" bandwagon</a> with the special-purpose acquisition company Executive Network Partnering, <a href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/former-house-speaker-paul-ryan-starts-blank-check-company-11597934227\">The Wall Street Journal</a> reported on August 20. Ryan will serve as the firm's chairman. The SPAC plans to raise $300 million in an initial public offering and trade under the ticker ENPC.</p><p><em><strong>Now read more markets coverage from Markets Insider and Business Insider:</strong></em></p><p><em><strong><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/bill-ackman-child-investing-letter-accounts-economic-wealth-inequality-capitalism-2020-8-1029548114\" data-analytics-position=\"1\" data-analytics-module=\"\">Billionaire Bill Ackman says mandatory investing accounts for every US child could combat wealth inequality</a></strong></em></p><p><em><strong><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/robinhood-sec-finra-investigation-march-trading-service-outage-stock-brokerage-2020-8-1029548651\" data-analytics-position=\"2\" data-analytics-module=\"\">Robinhood under investigation by SEC, FINRA for handling of day-long March outage, report says</a></strong></em></p><p><em><strong><a stocks that are poised to continue crushing the market as the 'shared favorites' of Wall Street's biggest investors</a></strong></em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 01:21:52","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","title":"Tesla Model S on autopilot slammed into a police car because the driver was watching a movie on his phone, authorities say","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/tesla-model-s-autopilot-crash-police-car-driver-watching-movie-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4943e660bf1f00280793e9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Tesla autopilot crash North Caroline\" height=\"958\" width=\"1282\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Nash County Sheriff&#39;s Office</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>A driver in North Carolina was watching a movie while driving his Tesla Model S when it careened into a police car, authorities said.&#160;</li><li>The man was charged with two crimes: not moving over for police, and watching TV while driving.&#160;</li><li>There have been many past incidents of careless drivers putting too much faith in the driver-assistance software, Autopilot, which has been criticized for its name.</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>A Tesla slammed into a North Carolina state trooper's cruiser as its driver, a doctor, watched a movie on his phone, authorities said.</p><p>The crash occurred around midnight on a rural stretch of a divided four-lane highway, where the officer was assisting a local sheriff's deputy in responding to a separate crash on the side of the roadway, when the Tesla ploughed into the cars, totaling both.</p><p>The driver, identified by police as Devainder Goli, a doctor from Raleigh, was charged with violating a state law that says motorists must move over for stopped emergency responders and for watching television while operating a vehicle. He could not be reached for comment.</p><p>Luckily no one was injured, the highway patrol said.</p><p>\"We were doing a simple lane closure and then death's suddenly there at our footsteps,\" <a href=\"https://www.cbs17.com/news/local-news/driver-was-watching-movie-when-tesla-plowed-into-nash-county-deputys-vehicle-troopers-say/\">Sheriff Kieth Stone told CBS 17</a>. \"It shows automation is never going to take the place of our motoring public paying attention, not texting, not being on the phone, but focusing on what you were doing: driving.\"</p><p>It's <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/feds-will-investigate-deadly-tesla-crash-in-california-2020-1\">far from the first time</a> a Tesla has <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tesla-autopilot-crashes-into-police-car-2019-12\">careened off the road</a> or <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/teslas-autopilot-faces-scrutiny-after-accidents-2018-5\">into other another vehicle</a> while operating on Autopilot, the company's name for its driver-assistance software that is not yet fully self driving. The rash of incidents come despite clear warnings and instructions, including alerts if a driver's hands leave the wheel for more than a few seconds.</p><p>That's led to criticism from public safety officials,<a href=\"https://www.mercurynews.com/2019/06/21/study-tesla-autopilot-misleading-overestimated-more-than-similar-technology/#:~:text=The%20IIHS%20also%20cited%20studies,said%20%E2%80%9Cit%20is%20important%20that\"> industry experts</a>, and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tesla-autopilot-claims-misleading-german-court-ruling-advertising-ban-2020-7\">consumer groups </a>that say the name &#8212; and CEO Elon Musk's rhetoric about its functionality &#8212;&#160;is misleading, and could be exacerbating the unsafe practices.</p><p>\"The people who misuse Autopilot, it's not because they're new to it and don't understand it,\" <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/elon-musk-defends-autopilot-against-criticism-misleading-name-accusations-2020-8\">Musk told Automotive News earlier this month.</a> \"The people who first use Autopilot are extremely paranoid about it. It's not like, 'If you just introduced a different name, I would have really treated it differently.' If something goes wrong with Autopilot, it's because someone is misusing it and using it directly contrary to how we've said it should be used.\"</p><div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><iframe src=\"https://www.facebook.com/plugins/post.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2FNashCountySO%2Fposts%2F3344871665579386&show_text=true&width=552&height=570&appId\" width=\"552\" height=\"570\" style=\"border:none;overflow:hidden\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" allowtransparency=\"true\" allow=\"encrypted-media\"></iframe></div><p>&#160;</p><p>&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read (Graham Rapier)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f4943e660bf1f00280793e9?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn55@2020_3/2020/08/31/17-22-11-638_9dad731774cfba1d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn51@2020_3/2020/08/31/17-22-14-421_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qFt09zgBBe4:BnFYM6_rdJ8:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn39@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-22-12-996_0ed54626fa86cf88.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qFt09zgBBe4:BnFYM6_rdJ8:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn23@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-22-08-553_6e9cf36ca8159ebd.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn76@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-22-07-798_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qFt09zgBBe4:BnFYM6_rdJ8:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn23@2020_6/2020/08/31/17-22-17-394_dc7434693da1fb55.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/qFt09zgBBe4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn23@2020_2/2020/08/31/17-22-09-696_fb6a4d0e65d249c1.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598894512910},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","title":"FAA clears Amazon's fleet of Prime Air drones for liftoff","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-prime-air-delivery-drones-faa-ruling-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d163f7ffa48002894d217?format=jpeg\" alt=\"amazon drones\" height=\"624\" width=\"832\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>&#34;The FAA supports innovation that is beneficial to the public, especially during a health or weather-related crisis,&#34; an agency spokesperson said in a statement to Business Insider.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Peter Endig/picture alliance via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>The Federal Aviation Administration has issued Amazon permission to begin conducting delivery drone operations.</li><li>Amazon's Prime Air drone project has been in the works since 2013.</li><li>The online retail giant received permission to begin testing drone deliveries in June 2019.</li><li>\"Amazon Prime Air's concept uses autonomous UAS to safely and efficiently deliver packages to customers,\" a FAA spokesperson said in a statement sent to Business Insider.</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>The Federal Aviation Administration will allow Amazon's fleet of Prime Air delivery drones to take flight.</p><p>A FAA spokesperson told Business Insider that the administration issued Amazon Prime Air its certificate on August 29. The Part 135 air carrier certificate allows Amazon to use \"unmanned aircraft systems,\" or UAS, in a commercial operation.</p><p>\"Amazon Prime Air's concept uses autonomous UAS to safely and efficiently deliver packages to customers,\" the spokesperson said in a statement sent to Business Insider. \"The FAA's role is to ensure that any UAS operation is performed safely. The FAA supports innovation that is beneficial to the public, especially during a health or weather-related crisis.\"</p><p>Amazon representatives did not immediately respond to Business Insider's request for comment.&#160;</p><p>\"This certification is an important step forward for Prime Air and indicates the FAA's confidence in Amazon's operating and safety procedures for an autonomous drone delivery service that will one day deliver packages to our customers around the world,\" Amazon Vice President and Prime Air Chief David Carbon told <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-08-31/amazon-s-drone-delivery-fleet-hits-milestone-with-faa-clearance\">Bloomberg</a>.</p><p>The certificate will allow Amazon to dive into operating a commercial drone delivery service, which has been in the works since 2013. The FAA gave Amazon <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-prime-air-drones-approved-by-faa-2019-6\">permission</a> to test its drones in the US in June 2019. FAA <a href=\"https://www.faa.gov/uas/advanced_operations/package_delivery_drone/\">regulations</a> hold that&#160; \"Part 135 certification is the only path for small drones to carry the property of another for compensation beyond visual line of sight.\"</p><p>But Amazon is not the only player in the delivery drones game. In July, regional grocery chain <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/rouses-markets-tests-unmanned-drone-grocery-delivery-with-deuce-drone-2020-7\">Rouses Markets</a> teamed up with last-mile delivery drone startup Deuce Drone for test flights in Alabama. The FAA has also issued Part 135 air carrier certificates to Alphabet's Wing Aviation and UPS' Flight Forward.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-prime-air-delivery-drones-faa-ruling-2020-8'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a 2020 16:20:29 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f4d165060bf1f0028079764?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"7979a3e2b8eda39abc89acbfa4e08fdb","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn56@2020_4/2020/08/31/17-22-24-142_4517c01704c8bcb7.webp","destWidth":832,"destHeight":624,"sourceBytes":21064,"destBytes":21064,"author":"insider@insider.com (Áine Cain)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f4d163f7ffa48002894d217?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn79@2020_3/2020/08/31/17-22-16-322_4b3ce4f41d0fce24.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn51@2020_3/2020/08/31/17-22-14-421_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=gp-NrXJK-68:1GR_ZRGip-g:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn59@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-22-00-005_e5faf01b8ad86324.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=gp-NrXJK-68:1GR_ZRGip-g:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn15@2020_4/2020/08/31/17-22-13-845_feba78006a8766db.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn76@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-22-07-798_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=gp-NrXJK-68:1GR_ZRGip-g:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn39@2020_6/2020/08/31/17-21-57-455_11c59a04bdcca6fc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/gp-NrXJK-68":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn55@2020_6/2020/08/31/17-22-14-380_4c630d279e079c77.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598894512820},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","title":"The pandemic could lead to a 'baby bust' of almost half a million fewer births, a major think tank projects","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/pandemic-could-lead-to-baby-bust-half-million-fewer-births-2020-6","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e7d074792e191072b413b34?format=jpeg\" alt=\"pregnant women and coronavirus 2x1\" height=\"600\" width=\"800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>There could be almost half a million fewer births next year.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Crystal Cox/Business Insider; Samantha Lee/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li><a href=\"https://www.brookings.edu/research/half-a-million-fewer-children-the-coming-covid-baby-bust/\">Brookings Institute economists</a> predict that the coronavirus pandemic will lead to what they call a \"baby bust,\" or a decline in pregnancy and birth rates.</li><li>In fact, the pandemic could result in 300,000 to 500,000 fewer births next year, according to Melissa S. Kearney and Phillip Levine, coauthors of the Brookings report.</li><li>Wharton Professor Mauro Guillen warned in a <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/posts/mauro-guillen-719baa1b_coronavirus-socialsecurity-immigration-activity-6704403779447504897-zy7h/\">LinkedIn post</a> that this has dire implications for the economy, projecting the over-60 population will be the largest consumer group by 2030, by which time the Social Security Trust Fund Ratio will fall below the 100% financial adequacy level, per a <a href=\"https://www.ssa.gov/oact/tr/2020/tr2020.pdf\">federal projection</a>.&#160;</li><li>While some have joked about the potential of a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-pandemic-create-new-generation-after-gen-z-2020-4\">pandemic baby boom</a> as couples are holed up together, Kearney and Levine note that speculation about baby booms after events like blizzards or blackouts often does not hold up.</li><li>Instead, economic loss, insecurity, and uncertainty are the primary reasons that the pandemic will lead to a decrease in births.&#160;The 1918 Spanish Flu led to a decline in birth rates &#8212; because of war manufacturing, there wasn't a recession then, only an economic contraction.</li><li>The US <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-recession-economy-february-coronavirus-nber-official-data-2020-6\">fell into a recession in February</a> amid the coronavirus pandemic and the shutdowns it necessitated. The unemployment <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/5-charts-how-coronavirus-economic-fallout-compares-to-great-recession-2020-5#the-unemployment-rate-in-april-spiked-to-a-post-world-war-ii-high-of-147-well-above-the-great-recession-era-peak-of-100-in-october-2009-3\">spiked to 14.7% in April</a>, well above the 10% peak during the Great Recession peak. While it has come down through the summer, it <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/july-jobs-report-economy-adds-million-jobs-unemployment-declines-2020-8\">remains over 10%</a> heading into September.</li><li>The Great Recession also led to a large drop in birth rates, with a drop of almost 400,000 fewer births from 2007 to 2012.</li><li>\"A deeper and longer lasting recession will then mean lower lifetime income for some people, which means that some women will not just delay births, but they will decide to have fewer children,\" Kearney and Levine write.</li><li>A decline in birth rate could hurt the economy in the long term, <a href=\"https://www.axios.com/fertility-rate-births-us-baby-bust-03c85100-806e-4e66-9daa-f3fd69072dce.html\">as smaller workforces must takeover the cost to care</a> for aging populations. In Japan, experts already worry a <a href=\"https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2020/08/29ee13180bbe-focus-fears-pandemic-worsening-birth-rate-exacerbating-japans-aging-crisis.html\">pandemic-fueled baby bust could worsen the country's aging crisis</a> that strains the working population.</li><li>Brookings found states with more severe recessions had larger declines in birth rates.</li><li>&#160;Kearney and Levine write, \"As any parent will tell you, children come at a cost. They require outlays of money, time, and energy.\"</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/pandemic-could-lead-to-baby-bust-half-million-fewer-births-2020-6'>Business Insider</a></div><div inequality","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/bill-ackman-child-investing-letter-accounts-economic-wealth-inequality-capitalism-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4ce4e37ffa48002894d170?format=jpeg\" alt=\"FILE PHOTO: William &#39;Bill&#39; Ackman, CEO and Portfolio Manager of Pershing Square Capital Management, speaks during the Sohn Investment Conference in New York City, U.S., May 8, 2017. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo\" height=\"2921\" width=\"5843\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Bill Ackman.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul><li><strong>Wealth inequality poses a \"black-swan-type\" risk to investors and US capitalism, but the government can work to solve it, the Pershing Square Capital founder Bill Ackman <a href=\"https://pershingsquareholdings.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Pershing-Square-Holdings-Ltd.-June-2020-Interim.pdf\">said in a letter to investors</a>.</strong></li><li><strong>The billionaire defended capitalism as \"the best system for maximizing the size of the economic pie\" but said wage growth had \"not kept pace\" with wealth creation for the wealthiest Americans.</strong></li><li><strong>The US could combat the disparity with mandatory investing accounts for every US-born child, Ackman said, adding that if returns continue to average 8% per year, a $6,750 investment at birth would yield more than $1 million by retirement.</strong></li><li><strong>The government could also mandate that companies set aside a portion of workers' wages for a tax-free investment fund, similar to Australia's pension system, Ackman added.</strong></li><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestutm_source=msn.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_content=msn-slideshow&utm_campaign=bodyurl?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestts&#38;utm_medium=ingest\">Visit the Business Insider homepage for more stories</a>.</strong></li></ul><hr ><p>The hedge-fund manager Bill Ackman said he views wealth inequality in the US as a \"black-swan-type\" risk for investors and sees two potential solutions for aiding lower- and middle-income Americans.</p><p>In a <a href=\"https://pershingsquareholdings.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Pershing-Square-Holdings-Ltd.-June-2020-Interim.pdf\">letter</a> to Pershing Square Capital investors, the billionaire defended capitalism as \"the best system for maximizing the size of the economic pie\" but said stagnant wage growth for most Americans presented \"one of the principal problems\" with the US economy. If the disparity worsens, a growing share of Americans will push for radical changes to the system or look to overhaul it, he added.</p><p>\"Like those who rent rather than own their homes and thereby have no love lost for their landlords, Americans that have no ownership in the success of capitalism, and who are suffering economically, are more motivated to turn toward Socialism or other alternatives,\" Ackman wrote.</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-picks-to-buy-hedge-mutual-funds-market-favorites-goldman-2020-8\" data-analytics-position=\"3\" data-analytics-module=\"\">GOLDMAN SACHS: Buy these 9 stocks that are poised to continue crushing the market as the 'shared favorites' of Wall Street's biggest investors</a></em></p><p>It's incumbent on those benefiting the most to close the wealth gap and improve capitalism for the rest, the billionaire said. One solution Ackman offered was a program that shares investing gains with those who can't afford to enter the market.</p><p>He said the government could fund investment accounts for every child born in the US that would invest in zero-fee stock index funds, compound tax-free, and be tapped only at retirement. If return rates continue to average 8% per year, a $6,750 investment at birth could yield more than $1 million by age 65, Ackman said, adding that such a program would cost the US about $26 billion a year if the birth rate holds steady.</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-crash-david-morgan-report-expert-warns-likely-meltdown-2020-8\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">'Basically one mass manipulation': A market expert unloads on the central bank-driven 'failure' of the modern financial system &#8212; and says another stock meltdown is likely coming</a></em></p><p>\"Compounded returns over time are indeed one of the great wonders of the world, and every day we wait to address this issue, the problem looms larger,\" the Pershing Square Capital manager wrote.</p><p>Another option involves a mandate for corporations to set aside a fixed share of workers' salaries in a tax-free investment account for all workers whose funds could be withdrawn only at retirement. Ackman said Australia's superannuation system, founded in 1991, proved that such programs can succeed &#8212; the country boasts the world's fourth-largest pension and holds nearly $2.7 trillion.</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-picks-to-buy-cheap-companies-strong-earnings-morgan-stanley-2020-8\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">MORGAN STANLEY: Buy these 12 underappreciated stocks that offer strong profit growth and are due for a surge</a></em></p><p>Mandatory investing accounts would help a larger share of Americans save for retirement, but they could also serve as an important lesson in investing, the billionaire said. The barrier to entry for retail investors has never been lower, with trading fees slashed in recent years and brokerages competing with various incentives to pull in new customers.</p><p>A government-led push for equities-investing accounts could \"encourage greater financial literacy\" and share the stock market's gains with more of the US population, Ackman said.</p><p><em><strong>Now read more markets coverage from Markets Insider and Business Insider:</strong></em></p><p><em><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-crash-david-rosenberg-dot-com-tech-bubble-distortions-2020-8\" data-analytics-position=\"5\" data-analytics-module=\"\">35-year market vet David Rosenberg warns the stock market's rally features distortions that were glaring during the tech bubble &#8212; and lays out his plausible scenario for a crash</a></strong></em></p><p><em><strong><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/stock-market-outlook-4-reasons-corporate-profits-resilient-coronavirus-recession-2020-8-1029546200\" data-analytics-position=\"1\" data-analytics-module=\"\">A Wall Street chief strategist details 4 reasons why big-company profits have been remarkably resilient during the pandemic &#8212; and explains how that's helped the red-hot stock rally</a><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-crash-david-rosenberg-dot-com-tech-bubble-distortions-2020-8\" data-analytics-position=\"5\" href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/us-tech-stocks-worth-more-european-stock-market-apple-microsoft-2020-8-1029545001\" data-analytics-position=\"3\" data-analytics-module=\"\">The US tech sector is now worth more than the entire European stock market, Bank of America says</a></strong></em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a Song/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul><li><strong><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/tsla-stock\">Tesla</a> stock jumped as much as 12% in its first day of post-split trading on Monday.&#160;</strong></li><li><strong>The electric vehicle maker announced August 11 that it would enact a 5-for-1 stock split, and started trading at the new price Monday.&#160;</strong></li><li><strong>Still, the automaker's rally hasn't slowed down. Shares are up more than 470% this year.&#160;</strong></li><li><strong><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/tsla-stock\">Watch Tesla trade live on Markets Insider</a>.</strong></li><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/\">Read more on Business Insider.&#160;</a></strong></li></ul><hr ><p>Tesla surged as much as 12% on Monday to $497 per share in the company's first day of post-stock-split trading, extending the automaker's blistering rally.&#160;</p><p>The company announced on August 11 that it would enact a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tesla-5-1-stock-split-after-shares-soar-this-year-2020-8?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestgest\">5-for-1 stock split</a> after its recent rally pushed shares above $2,000 a piece. Since the announcement, Tesla shares have added more than 70%, even though a stock split changes nothing about a <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/tesla-stock-price-since-announcing-stock-split-two-days-2020-8-1029501926\">company's underlying fundamentals</a>.&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more</strong>: <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-crash-david-rosenberg-dot-com-tech-bubble-distortions-2020-8\" data-analytics-position=\"5\" data-analytics-module=\"\">35-year market vet David Rosenberg warns the stock market's rally features distortions that were glaring during the tech bubble &#8212; and lays out his plausible scenario for a crash</a></em></p><p>Still, the split may encourage more small investors who couldn't afford the stock's pre-split price.</p><p>\"We believe the stock split decision was a smart move by Tesla and its Board given the parabolic move in shares over the past six months,\" wrote Wedbush analyst Daniel Ives in a Monday note. He adjusted his price target on Tesla shares to $380 with a bull case of $700 and reaffirmed his neutral rating following the split.&#160;</p><p>Also on Monday, <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/aapl-stock\">Apple</a> shares gained after its own <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/apple-stock-split-shares-performed-year-after-previous-historical-returns-2020-8-1029548855\">4-for-1 stock split went into effect</a>. It's the company's fifth stock split ever.&#160;</p><p>Tesla has gained more than <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tesla-5-1-stock-split-after-shares-soar-this-year-2020-8?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestgest\">472% year-to-date</a>.</p><figure>\n\t<img +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f0dd1e73ad8616e8d6c1e73?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"b2f8c44800cad5d74b78476f329c7195","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn27@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-21-55-891_b850595cf3185fcc.webp","destWidth":2222,"destHeight":1667,"sourceBytes":800134,"destBytes":800134,"author":"insider@insider.com
