href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-kitchenaid-attachment\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The best KitchenAid attachments</a></h3>\n <p>The versatility of the KitchenAid stand mixer increased tenfold when you begin to utilize the attachment hub on the front of the machine. It allows you to use accessories that transform your mixer into a pasta machine, a food processor, a meat grinder, and more. Some can even replace other appliances in your kitchen. These are <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-kitchenaid-attachment\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">the best KitchenAid attachments</a> you can buy.</p>\n <hr />\n <h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-grind-meat-kitchen-aid\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">How to use a KitchenAid stand mixer to grind your own meat</a></h3>\n <p>Both KitchenAid and several third-party companies make&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-kitchenaid-attachment\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">attachments</a> you can use to grind meat with your stand mixer. With our foolproof tips, you can have freshly ground burgers, sausage, and other ground meat treats.</p>\n <hr />\n <h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-make-sausage-with-a-kitchenaid-stand-mixer\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">How to make sausage with a KitchenAid stand mixer</a></h3>\n <p>You can make fresh sausage with your stand mixer using an array of attachments from KitchenAid and third-party vendors. Here's our method for making fresh, homemade sausage in a snap.</p> Check out our other kitchen appliance guides \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/590359502f6ae433008b5082?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Breville BES870XL Barista Express Espresso Machine\" height=\"1200\" width=\"1600\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Breville</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> \n <h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-espresso-machine\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The best espresso machines</a></h3>\n <p>Coffee lovers start out innocently enough with drip filters, French presses, milk frothers, and stovetop espresso makers; but then next thing you know, they're browsing Amazon for full-on espresso machines with all the bells and whistles. These are <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-espresso-machine\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">the best espresso machines</a> you can buy.</p>\n <hr />\n <h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-blender\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The best blenders</a></h3>\n <p>When selecting a blender for your kitchen, you're going to want one that's powerful enough to do whatever job you need, whether it's creating a simple smoothie or crushing ice. Although blenders all seem to perform the same task, there are a few different types, each with its own unique features: conventional, multi-function, personal, and immersion. These are <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-blender\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">the best blenders</a>.</p>\n <hr />\n <h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-food-processor\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The best food processors</a></h3>\n <p>One of the unsung heroes of this electronic kitchen revolution is the humble food processor. While not as common as electric ranges and microwaves, a food processor is one of those appliances that will leave you wondering how you ever lived without one. These are <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-food-processor\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">the best food processors</a>.</p>\n <hr />\n <h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-juicer\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The best juicers</a></h3>\n <p>The nutritional benefits of starting your day with fruits and vegetables are undeniable, but so is the financial hit of being a juice bar regular (if you go five times a week, we're talking hundreds — if not thousands — of dollars a year). With a juicer, however, you can offset the cost of your healthy habit by squeezing your own greens at home. These are <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-juicer\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">the best juicers</a> you can buy.</p> \n</div>\n<div class=\"read-original\">\n Read the original Here are Optum Ventures' 12 biggest investments.</a></h3>\n  <ul>\n   <li>Optum Ventures is a $600 million venture fund associated with UnitedHealth Group, the biggest health insurer in the US.</li>\n   <li>The fund launched in 2017 and has invested in 29 startups since its founding, with a focus on digital health, a spokesman confirmed to Business Insider.</li>\n   <li>The fund regularly reinvests &#8212; all under $25</a></li></ul><p>The catch-22 of having your office where you live is that you're surrounded by well, your home. Instead of the usual work setup with an ergonomic rolling chair, large desk, and organizers of every kind, you're working with a kitchen table and chair setup that contribute to a longer and less enjoyable workday.&#160;</p><p>These items aren't going to keep all the distractions at bay, but after working in our new home offices for the past six months, they've definitely kept us more focused, productive, and comfortable &#8212; even at our kitchen tables.</p><h2>Here are 22 useful desk accessories:</h2>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tA balance board\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4824a0cd2fec00296a4aee?format=jpeg\" alt=\"useful desk acessories\" height=\"750\" width=\"1000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Fluidstance</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<h3><a href=\"https://go.skimresources.com?id=35871X943606&#38;xs=1&#38;url=https%3A%2F%2Ffluidstance.com%2Fproducts%2Fthe-level-balance-board-for-standing-desk%3Fvariant%3D32000472204\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Fluidstance The Level</a></h3><div id=\"ProductCard_5f492f3158c24d7e7c6563ff\" style=\"position:relative; display:block; width: 100%\"><iframe src=\"https://produktor.businessinsider.com/productCardService?id=5f492f3158c24d7e7c6563ff&type=button&live=true\" width=\"100%\" height=\"150%\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\" style=\"position:absolute; top:0; left: 0\"></iframe></div><p>I had a makeshift standing desk setup at home, and if you've ever had something similar, you know the position can be tiring on your feet. Fluidstance's balance boards help you stabilize your body and relieve some of the tension of standing, plus they're just plain fun to use. It's also weighted so it's hard to knock over, and if a real cat happened to walk on my desk, they'd struggle to knock it off. <strong>&#8212; Malarie Gokey, deputy editor</strong></p>\n\tA wireless mouse\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5c5865e2b357334515627e8b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"41DOPNs5McL\" height=\"601\" width=\"800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Amazon</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<h3><a href=\"https://goto.walmart.com/c/196318/565706/9383?veh=aff&#38;sourceid=imp_000011112222333344&#38;u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.walmart.com%2Fip%2FAnker-2-4G-Wireless-Vertical-Ergonomic-Optical-Mouse-800-1200-1600DPI-5-Buttons-Black%2F41221388\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener nofollow nofollow sponsored\">Anker Wireless Mouse</a></h3><div id=\"ProductCard_5f21a0864e52b72bdb2c3130\" style=\"position:relative; display:block; width: 100%\"><iframe src=\"https://produktor.businessinsider.com/productCardService?id=5f21a0864e52b72bdb2c3130&type=button&live=true\" width=\"100%\" height=\"150%\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\" style=\"position:absolute; top:0; left: 0\"></iframe></div><p>It's not just that this mouse is wireless and thus de-clutters my space, it's also that it's ergonomic. It's never glitched out on me and it always does what I need it to do &#8212; it's that simple. &#8212;<strong> Sally Kaplan, senior editor</strong></p>\n\tAn insulated sport water bottle\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5c58b5c6e43f405236539186?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Takeya Actives 18oz Insulated Stainless Steel Water Bottle with Insulated Spout Lid\" height=\"650\" width=\"866\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Takeya</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<h3><a href=\"https://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/6415797/type/dlg/https://www.overstock.com/Home-Garden/Takeya-Actives-18-oz.-Insulated-Stainless-Steel-Water-Bottle/25441011/product.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener nofollow nofollow sponsored\">Takeya Actives Insulated Stainless Water Bottle</a></h3><div id=\"ProductCard_5f21a13bf34d054b973e6817\" style=\"position:relative; display:block; width: 100%\"><iframe src=\"https://produktor.businessinsider.com/productCardService?id=5f21a13bf34d054b973e6817&type=button&live=true\" width=\"100%\" height=\"150%\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\" style=\"position:absolute; top:0; left: 0\"></iframe></div><p>I use this water bottle everywhere I go. It keeps my tea hot for hours, my cold brew <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/takeya-stainless-steel-water-bottle-review-2019-1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">cold for over 24 hours (with ice cubes intact)</a>, and has a conveniently durable build and no-drip or drop design for the gym. It's pretty cheap for a stainless steel water bottle, and the clip at the top means I can attach it to backpacks or duffel bags with clip-on straps for easy carrying. <strong>&#8212; Mara Leighton, senior reporter</strong></p>\n\tA weekly planner\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5c5865e2a26516462660a02f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"71xW0IJLdxL._SL1500_\" height=\"1243\" width=\"1657\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Amazon</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<h3><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01MU3FEGD/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&#38;tag=biip_020119_desk-products-20&#38;camp=1789&#38;creative=9325&#38;linkCode=as2&#38;creativeASIN=B01MU3FEGD&#38;linkId=3df7237e81d1ab6e37e17de447e0920a\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener nofollow nofollow sponsored\">Hashi Weekly Planner Pad</a></h3><div id=\"ProductCard_5d0a3956b587c626514c82d3\" style=\"position:relative; display:block; width: 100%\"><iframe src=\"https://produktor.businessinsider.com/productCardService?id=5d0a3956b587c626514c82d3&type=button&live=true\" width=\"100%\" height=\"150%\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\" style=\"position:absolute; top:0; left: 0\"></iframe></div><p>Between my Post-Its, Trello board, and this weekly desk planner, I make to-do lists for my to-do lists. I love this planner for its simple weekly layout, lack of dates that ensure it lasts longer than a year, and its adorable designs. As you flip through the weeks, you get cute cacti, airplanes, flowers, and other fun designs. It doesn't take up much desk space, either. I have mine right above my keyboard so I can refer to it all day, every day.<strong> &#8212; Malarie Gokey, deputy editor</strong></p>\n\tWhere to find more desk recommendations\n\t<figure>\n\t<img :"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn87@2020_2/2020/08/31/17-21-58-074_c1b969adac5a2789.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=LmwQPz_atzU:zPz8mYi5cLE:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn24@2020_4/2020/08/31/17-22-21-569_c17a76f9a1d56818.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn76@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-22-07-798_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=LmwQPz_atzU:zPz8mYi5cLE:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn12@2020_2/2020/08/31/17-22-16-700_b780d59699d2de19.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/LmwQPz_atzU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn47@2020_6/2020/08/31/17-21-58-589_0f722cc0a016e757.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598894512933},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","title":"US dominance and Chinese ambition are driving a new laser arms race","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-dominance-chinese-ambition-driving-new-laser-arms-race-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d07f860bf1f002807971b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"solid state laser uss ponce\" height=\"2128\" width=\"4256\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>USS Ponce conducts an operational demonstration of the Laser Weapon System in the Arabian Gulf.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"http://www.navy.mil/view_image.asp?id=190357\" target=\"_blank\">US Navy photo by John F. Williams/Released</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>The US is the leader in directed-energy weapons, but China has been accused of targeting American planes with military-grade laser beams.</li><li>Both sides are developing laser weapons and equipping warships to be able to launch them.</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-stringify-link=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>The use of high-energy lasers for naval applications is gathering pace among the world's military powers, with <a href=\"https://www.scmp.com/news/china\" data-v-5f87d536=\"\">China</a> among those set to race the <a href=\"https://www.scmp.com/topics/united-states\" data-v-5f87d536=\"\">United States</a> for supremacy.</p><p data-v-7092c704=\"\" data-v-179ac1eb=\"\">Directed-energy weapons based on lasers can offer low cost per shot and almost limitless magazines to provide an efficient and effective means of defending against missile salvoes or swarms of unmanned systems.</p><p data-v-7092c704=\"\" data-v-179ac1eb=\"\">Many countries, such as the US, China, Israel, France, Germany and Russia, have been researching the weapons for a long time, and major powers are ramping up their development to gain an upper hand.</p><p data-v-7092c704=\"\" data-v-179ac1eb=\"\"></p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d092760bf1f0028079722?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Navy laser weapon USS Portland\" height=\"549\" width=\"800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>USS Portland conducts a Solid State Laser - Technology Maturation Laser Weapon System Demonstrator, May 16, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">US Navy</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p data-v-7092c704=\"\" data-v-179ac1eb=\"\">Song Zhongping, a Hong Kong-based military commentator, said laser weapons were among those with the potential to change the face of warfare, and were of great importance.</p><p data-v-7092c704=\"\" data-v-179ac1eb=\"\">\"An arms race of laser weapons has long begun,\" he said. \"The US has a more solid technological foundation, but China is working to narrow the gap.</p><p data-v-7092c704=\"\" data-v-179ac1eb=\"\">\"Laser weapons can also be seen as an important symbol of the <a href=\"https://www.scmp.com/news/china/military\" data-v-5f87d536=\"\">Chinese military</a>'s transformation, given that their adoption will change the form of future warfare.\"</p><p data-v-7092c704=\"\" data-v-179ac1eb=\"\">The US has been researching directed energy since the 1960s, according to a Congressional Research Service report in early August, and it is unquestionably the leader in developing laser weapons.</p><p data-v-7092c704=\"\" data-v-179ac1eb=\"\">In May, the US Navy's USS Portland ship tested a laser weapon capable of destroying aerial, sea and land-based threats in the Pacific, according to the US Pacific Fleet.</p><p data-v-7092c704=\"\" data-v-179ac1eb=\"\">The American navy installed a laser weapon aboard the Arleigh Burke-class destroyer USS Dewey in November, before announcing it in late February, according to Military.com.</p><p data-v-7092c704=\"\" data-v-179ac1eb=\"\">Called the Optical Dazzling Interdictor, Navy, or ODIN, the system is the technological successor of the Laser Weapons System (LaWS) &#8211; a 30-kilowatt laser <a href=\"https://www.scmp.com/news/world/article/1661268/lethal-laser-weapon-deployed-uss-ponce-persian-gulf\" data-v-5f87d536=\"\">installed in 2014 on the amphibious transport dock USS Ponce</a>, which was the US' first operational directed-energy weapon.</p><p data-v-7092c704=\"\" data-v-179ac1eb=\"\">The US Navy expects to have eight warships it can equip with the ODIN within the next three years, according to a report in early July by automotive website The Drive.</p><p data-v-7092c704=\"\" data-v-179ac1eb=\"\">China is also developing laser weapons, in both naval vessels and warplanes. In late July, state media reported that China had equipped its warships with advanced generators to power high-energy weapons such as lasers and railguns. The exact type of the vessels was not disclosed, but it was widely believed to be the country's most advanced destroyers, such as the Type 055 guided-missile destroyer.</p><p data-v-7092c704=\"\" data-v-179ac1eb=\"\"></p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d926e9e2e22af2ad809ada1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Type 055 Destroyer\" height=\"2438\" width=\"3968\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The upgraded version of the Chinese navy&#39;s Type 055 destroyer off Qingdao, eastern China, April 23, 2019.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Kyodo News Stills via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p data-v-7092c704=\"\" data-v-179ac1eb=\"\">A procurement notice published by China's People's Liberation Army in January showed that it could be developing the ability to attach a new laser weapon to its planes.</p><p data-v-7092c704=\"\" data-v-179ac1eb=\"\">Although the detailed requirements for such equipment are unknown, it is likely to be a new type of tactical assault weapon, rather than laser guidance devices for missiles that are already widely in use.</p><p data-v-7092c704=\"\" data-v-179ac1eb=\"\">Airborne laser pods would be mounted to Chinese warplanes such as the Shenyang J-15 \"Flying Shark\" carrier-based fighter, the J-20 \"Mighty Dragon\" heavy fighter, and support aircraft such as the Xian Y-20 heavy transport.</p><p data-v-7092c704=\"\" data-v-179ac1eb=\"\">The development of laser weapons by the US and China has already resulted in confrontations.</p><p data-v-7092c704=\"\" data-v-179ac1eb=\"\">In February, the US Navy said a Chinese warship fired a laser weapon at one of its surveillance aircraft. It published a post on Instagram warning the Chinese military that \"you don't want to play laser tag with us.\"</p><p data-v-7092c704=\"\" data-v-179ac1eb=\"\">This was not the first time the US had accused China of targeting its forces with laser weapons. In 2018, military officials warned pilots that a Chinese airbase in Djibouti may have targeted its planes with \"military-grade laser beams,\" which also caused a diplomatic protest.</p><p data-v-7092c704=\"\" data-v-179ac1eb=\"\">Regulation of such weapons' use has been in place for some time. In 1995, to help defuse potential future conflicts, the United Nations issued the Protocol on Blinding Laser Weapons, which came into force in July 1998. As of April 2018, the protocol had been agreed to by 108 nations.</p><p data-v-7092c704=\"\" data-v-179ac1eb=\"\">The protocol prohibits use of laser weapons specifically designed &#8212; as their sole combat function or as one of their combat functions &#8212; to cause permanent blindness.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/us-dominance-chinese-ambition-driving-new-laser-arms-race-2020-8'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=O6fghI8KUi0:23K3B5MxNnA:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=O6fghI8KUi0:23K3B5MxNnA:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=O6fghI8KUi0:23K3B5MxNnA:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=O6fghI8KUi0:23K3B5MxNnA:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=O6fghI8KUi0:23K3B5MxNnA:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=O6fghI8KUi0:23K3B5MxNnA:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/O6fghI8KUi0\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 31 Aug 2020 14:49:04 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f4d0bac7ffa48002894d1e0?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"3c0f9f5d179da0aaefd268bb03798044","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn31@2020_3/2020/08/31/17-21-55-772_63e591e76ffa5fa2.webp","destWidth":731,"destHeight":548,"sourceBytes":16620,"destBytes":16620,"author":"insider@insider.com (Kristin Huang)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f4d07f860bf1f002807971b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn56@2020_4/2020/08/31/17-22-27-333_c0a702110aac6112.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f4d092760bf1f0028079722?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn20@2020_4/2020/08/31/17-22-15-302_382327cc62734138.webp","https://i.insider.com/5d926e9e2e22af2ad809ada1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn60@2020_3/2020/08/31/17-22-19-546_9ca44f5ade1d0519.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn51@2020_3/2020/08/31/17-22-14-421_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=O6fghI8KUi0:23K3B5MxNnA:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn91@2020_3/2020/08/31/17-22-05-854_f3346ff6d2691a69.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=O6fghI8KUi0:23K3B5MxNnA:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn96@2020_4/2020/08/31/17-22-16-670_2362b2d0cfb05012.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn76@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-22-07-798_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=O6fghI8KUi0:23K3B5MxNnA:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn76@2020_2/2020/08/31/17-22-09-070_78b8ab90053698ed.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/O6fghI8KUi0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn15@2020_3/2020/08/31/17-22-18-595_1dc3a0b952860d89.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598894512854},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","title":"6 keys to an effective content marketing strategy — and 11 types of content you need to master","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/6-keys-effective-content-marketing-strategy-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f46ac8442f43f001ddff384?format=jpeg\" alt=\"woman typing on computer\" height=\"1039\" width=\"2079\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">10&#39;000 Hours/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>Content marketing is an effective strategy to establish your firm as a thought leader in your industry. But to create effective content, you must understand what content marketing actually is.&#160;</li><li>Impactful content marketing typically provides solutions to problems that your customers or readers might have. Examples include targeted emails, web content and white papers.&#160;</li><li>Content marketing should put your audience first and be published consistently and continuously. It should rarely, if ever, directly promote your brand.&#160;</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>On the internet, <a href=\"https://www.entrepreneur.com/topic/content\">content</a> is anything that expresses thoughts, information or experiences through written, visual, or audio form.</p><p>This article is content. The 95 million photos uploaded to Instagram today are content. The 500 hours' worth of videos uploaded to YouTube in the last 60 seconds are all content.</p><p>The internet is built with content and always has been. It also means everyone has content, and everyone creates it all the time.</p><p>That creates some confusion when it comes to <a href=\"https://expresswriters.com/how-to-explain-content-strategy/\">content versus content marketing</a>. A lot of content is intended to market a brand &#8230; but that doesn't mean the brand does content marketing.</p><p>Here's why.</p><h3><strong>What does content marketing really look like?</strong></h3><p>Content marketing is a strategic approach to marketing that emphasizes the creation and delivery of valuable content to attract, retain&#160;and convert a clearly defined audience.</p><p>In other words, it's using content strategically to provide solutions to problems that either your business or your readers have. Great examples abound:</p><ul><li>The fitness brand that creates a community and encourages its subscribers to share knowledge.</li><li>The home d&#233;cor retailer that distributes a monthly magazine on minimalism and good housekeeping practices.</li><li>The SaaS platform that uses gamification to encourage users to discover and get to know its features.</li><li>The travel company that uses a thrilling interactive website to hint at the experiences it offers.</li><li>The health supplement site that publishes a vegan recipe blog.</li></ul><p>Do you see a difference? All of these efforts position you as an <a href=\"https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/230259\">authority</a> in your industry, demonstrate your expertise in your topic over the long run and cultivate trust in your audience by putting their needs and interests first.</p><h3><strong>How to tell if you're doing it right</strong></h3><p>You're doing content marketing (and not just content creation or digital marketing) if your content:</p><ul><li><strong>Puts your audience first</strong>. Be customer-focused, not company-focused. You're delivering helpful, valuable content and letting the customer decide when they trust you enough to buy from you.</li><li><strong>Links back to a business goal or solution to a problem</strong>. You've laid out how your content works together to further your business goals.</li><li><strong>Rarely, if ever, actively promotes your brand outright</strong>. CTAs are great, but you aren't trying to push your readers to your solutions.</li><li><strong>Attracts readers to your turf</strong>. You're building authority by providing readers with a destination to which they can keep returning.</li><li><strong>Gets published consistently and continuously</strong>. You're building trust by proving you're an expert in the matter over time rather than publishing one-offs.</li><li><strong>Uses metrics to measure and optimize</strong>. You can identify what's performing well, and where you need to improve based on data.</li></ul><h3>To master content marketing, you must master these 11 content types.</h3><p>High-performing content is central to your content marketing, but the way you craft it can make or break your strategy. It's not enough to simply create eBooks, blogs&#160;and catchy social media that provide helpful information &#8230; that's still biased toward your brand.</p><p>People are catching on to even that now.</p><p>Yet, with all the content creation that you will still do, it can be easy to lose your focus. Here's an overview of how to use the eleven main types of content in content marketing:</p><ol><li><strong>Blogs</strong>. Make sure they're optimized for SEO because they're one of the best ways to boost your page ranks. <a href=\"https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/269879\">Include a CTA</a> and consider opening up comments for further engagement.</li><li><strong>Case studies</strong>. Illustrate your expertise by taking your readers on a journey that showcases solutions to their pain points.</li><li><strong>eBooks</strong>. They make great lead magnets, especially when you craft a magnetizing title and supply information people can't find elsewhere.</li><li><strong>Emails</strong>. Write direct, powerful, concise copy that contains information that can change your readers' lives. They're a direct line to your audience and can build long-lasting relationships when done well.</li><li><strong>Headlines</strong>. Powerful, compelling headlines <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=52cVkaZYP3A\">(that don't sound spammy</a>!) let your readers know exactly what they're getting. They're also a great way to convey brand with language.</li><li><strong>Meta titles and descriptions</strong>. Put yourself in your readers' shoes and let them know you have the answers they're searching for right now.</li><li><strong>Product descriptions</strong>. Optimize with keywords and describe products in terms of benefits rather than features.</li><li><strong>Social media posts</strong>. Create an experience that puts them at the center and encourages engagement. This helps your audience connect with your brand emotionally and can help you find their pain points.</li><li><strong>Video scripts</strong>. Tell your brand's story engagingly. You can also include the script text on the page to make your content more accessible, and boost SEO.</li><li><strong>Web content</strong>. Make important or helpful information prominent, include a clear CTA, and use high-quality images to craft a powerful message.</li><li><strong>White papers</strong>.&#160;Explore relevant topics in-depth and give your target audience ideas that they can apply to their own problems or daily life.</li></ol><h3>Content making content marketing work: an example</h3><p>By now, I hope I've demonstrated how content creation is intrinsic to content marketing. However, just because you're creating content, it doesn't mean you're doing content marketing.</p><p>I want to drive things home with an example.</p><p>Let's say that we're growing an athletic clothing brand and looking for ways to attract more customers to our e-commerce site. We've decided to turn to content marketing for help. It might look like this:</p><p><strong>1. You want to increase your brand's presence on Google and social media, but you don't want to constantly annoy your readers with ads. How else can you get your brand in front of your readers?</strong></p><p>You decide that the best way forward is to start a blog full of topics that interest your readers. A few things that come to mind include clean eating, exercising at home, and personal empowerment. You can also talk about clothes, of course,&#160;but your models can all wear your brand, which eliminates the need for more direct advertising.</p><p><strong>2. You start your blog, set up your social media&#160;and let your following know about it.</strong></p><p>Engagement metrics indicate that readers are most excited about exercising at home. Looking through their comments, you notice that things like staying focused, finding the right space, and keeping a schedule are all major pain points that they have.</p><p><strong>3. You respond by creating an online guide to exercising at home.</strong></p><p>You use a combination of eBooks chock-full of challenges that are available as lead magnets, and video&#160;tutorials for exercises hosted on your site. To demonstrate how popular your guides are, you create a way for users to record their progress and encourage each other.</p><p><strong>4. To maintain engagement, you start up an email newsletter with the latest challenges, shoutouts for people who have achieved their goals&#160;and occasionally a promo here or there.</strong></p><p>Throughout this, you continue to grow your online community, adding more content to your blog that addresses questions or pain points. You even start a hashtag that your followers can use to highlight their fitness efforts so that they can spread the word about you.</p><p><strong>5. At some point, you realize that you can enrich your readers' experience with case studies and white papers.</strong></p><p>You begin to include \"white papers\"&#160;about health and fitness that are relevant to your target audience. You also start to create case studies of \"success stories\" from your community.</p><p><strong>6. As fitness centers start to notice what you're doing, you start getting offers for sponsored classes&#160;and requests to sell your brand in their shops.</strong></p><p>Your content marketing is now extending your brand's reach into the offline world. You'll continue all of the efforts above, as the results are feeding further content production.</p><p>Can you spot all eleven content types above? Look carefully. They're here.</p><p>(Bonus: Do you know what brand I just described? Spoiler: This is Athleta's content marketing strategy. Check it out at&#160;https://events.athleta.com/)</p><h3>Now you know the difference between content and content marketing in 2020.</h3><p>The main difference between content versus content marketing? Content marketing involves a lot more than just content creation. In fact, the emphasis isn't content creation at all, but crafting an experience that improves the lives of your readers. If you're putting your readers first, addressing pain points&#160;and producing exceptional quality content consistently, then you'll grow your brand while you cultivate authority and trust. That's content marketing.</p><p>Hopefully, I've left you with an idea or two about your content marketing strategy. Now, go forth and convert that target audience into passionate fans.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/6-keys-effective-content-marketing-strategy-2020-8'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a 2020 13:02:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5ed56a9d2618b930c97418f4?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"f2931cd2f248ceea41604a81c05afa39","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn67@2020_5/2020/08/31/17-21-55-742_108927038b02f2c6.webp","destWidth":1421,"destHeight":1065,"sourceBytes":70012,"destBytes":70012,"author":"insider@insider.com (Julia McCoy)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f46ac8442f43f001ddff384?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn92@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-22-08-050_11d921fce74c6c18.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn51@2020_3/2020/08/31/17-22-14-421_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=eUNegOW8do0:JjUFK5GO3gY:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn23@2020_5/2020/08/31/17-22-10-898_1aaf7de7fcb4d9df.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=eUNegOW8do0:JjUFK5GO3gY:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn91@2020_2/2020/08/31/17-22-15-035_93b763f61bb9d53d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn76@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-22-07-798_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=eUNegOW8do0:JjUFK5GO3gY:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn35@2020_6/2020/08/31/17-22-11-428_37deecff7866d5e6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/eUNegOW8do0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn3@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-22-00-792_e8f88ec1afd621a8.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598894512918},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","title":"How to get rid of your firm's workaholic culture in 3 steps","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/get-rid-of-your-firms-workaholic-culture-in-3-steps-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f46c690cd2fec00296a4616?format=jpeg\" alt=\"employees office\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Yes, you should turn off your work notifications.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Moyo Studio/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>With the new WFH world, it can be tempting to WFH 24/7 &#8212; but this doesn't create a healthy working culture for employees.&#160;</li><li>Experts suggest that a non-toxic workplace starts from leadership; when leadership sets up expectations and acts as an example, the rest of the company will follow.&#160;</li><li>A few strategies: set \"on\" and \"off\" hours (no 2 a.m. emails), turn off notifications after work and on weekends, and create a culture of honesty around what employees can and can't do.</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>How can company culture positively impact employee well-being?</p><p>According to British business magnate <a href=\"https://www.entrepreneur.com/topic/richard-branson\">Richard Branson</a>, it all comes down to treating people like the capable adults they are. \"Flexible working encourages our staff to find a better balance between their work and private lives,\" he <a href=\"https://www.virgin.com/disruptors/what-employee-wellbeing-means-me-richard-branson\">notes</a>. \"Through this balance, they become happier and more productive.\"</p><p>In a time when people are trying to navigate their workdays while simultaneously looking after small children and other personal responsibilities, these words couldn't ring more true.</p><p>During the worldwide <a href=\"https://www.entrepreneur.com/topic/health\">health</a> crisis, the need for boundaries between work and home has become even more critical. Many entrepreneurs might erroneously believe that sending emails at all hours of the day isn't problematic since their employees are now working from home. But what they're actually doing is promoting an unhealthy, \"always-on\" company culture that keeps people chained to their devices.</p><p>Writing for <a href=\"https://hbr.org/2020/06/how-different-personality-types-cope-with-an-always-on-culture\">Harvard Business Review</a>, John Hackston explains that, \"Technology can empower people, but it can also make them feel <a href=\"https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1201/1078.10580530/45520.22.4.20050901/90026.2?journalCode=uism20\">enslaved</a>. By thinking carefully about how and when to use it, you can find your own sweet spot. Amid the current crisis, that's more important than ever.\"</p><h2>\"Always-on\" has become the default</h2><p>Let me pose this question: How often do you take your smartphone with you to lunch or dinner? How about to bed? If you take a moment to tally up the number of times you've received work notifications outside of <a href=\"https://www.entrepreneur.com/topic/work-hours\">work hours</a>, you'd likely lose count.&#160;</p><p>When I tell you that, as entrepreneurs, we are \"always-on,\" I am referring to this habit of not distinguishing between work and personal time. Many of us may have inadvertently set our company culture to reflect our own lax boundaries around technology.&#160;</p><p>I know that when I first founded <a href=\"https://www.jotform.com/\">my startup</a>, I had this misplaced belief that answering emails till midnight or during weekends made me more productive. I had yet to establish the firm work policies I now have in place.&#160;</p><p>Research <a href=\"https://www.isonderhouden.nl/doc/pdf/arnoldbakker/articles/articles_arnold_bakker_379.pdf\">shows</a> that as supervisors, we need to be careful in creating harmful expectations when it comes to smartphone use.&#160;</p><p>As Hackston points out:&#160;\"And now that so many of us are working from home, communicating with our colleagues exclusively via electronic media, the boundaries between home and work can become increasingly blurred, making it even more difficult to switch off.\"</p><p>Many of us might figure that since we're working from home, we'll get all our emails done later in the night or on Sunday morning. But what we often don't take into consideration, is that we're significantly contributing to employee distress, and, ultimately, an unhealthy environment.</p><h2>The change starts at the level of leadership</h2><p>As leaders, it's up to us to set a calm and productive culture that wards off <a href=\"https://www.entrepreneur.com/topic/burnout\">burnout</a>.&#160;</p><p>The problem with blurring the border between work and downtime is that it leaks into other areas of your life like your health, family and personal time.&#160;</p><p>One 2012 <a href=\"https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0268401212000606\">study</a> found the more information overload we experience, our productivity and performance decreases. And not only that, our decision-making and ability to innovate also become compromised. Other <a href=\"http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2009/08/21/0903620106.abstract\">research</a> shows that heavy multitaskers are less capable of doing several things at once compared to light multitaskers.</p><p>In other words, constant interruptions and not giving your team the head-space to be fully present in their personal lives will eventually lead to poor work results.&#160;</p><p>So, what's to be done?</p><p>To paraphrase Branson's insight, the key is to treat your team how you would like to be treated. Below I offer an alternative path for cultivating more balance.</p><h2>Ways to dismantle workaholic culture</h2><p>1. Set the pace. It's important that we note how our everyday habits perpetuate larger work behaviors. Meaning, we are setting the precedent for how employees feel they should act. For example, if I answer phone calls while I'm having dinner with family, I'm creating an expectation that it's fine to blur these lines between our work and home life. If we don't create boundaries around our own work hours, others won't think they have the right to not immediately answer calls.</p><p>2. Allow your team to switch off. During the first five years of JotForm, we had just four employees. It was relatively easy to keep track of communication. But as we grew, I decided that promoting a healthy company culture meant adjusting our policies to reflect our values. Instead of simply paying lip-service to these ideals, I make it a point to walk my talk, and I do this in several ways:&#160;</p><ul><li>By encouraging my team to delete their Slack app on weekends, the amount of work related correspondence during our employee's downtime is limited.&#160;</li><li>By defining the parameters of \"on\" and \"off\" hours, team members who are eager to please will assume they should always \"be on\" unless you tell them otherwise. Communicating clear expectations helps them guard their time better.</li><li>By not stressing them out with excessive emails, I respect their personal time. <a href=\"https://www.fastcompany.com/90510021/managers-think-twice-before-you-send-that-2-a-m-email\">I've written before</a> why we should refrain from sending 2 a.m. emails. Keep in mind, receiving that ping in the dead of night is disrupting their sleep and causing unneeded stress during a time that's already stressful enough. In making sure I schedule my send time for business hours, I'm letting them know I respect their health and wellbeing.</li></ul><p>3. Create a culture of honesty.&#160;Finally, breaking a work addiction mindset involves transparency on what we all can and can't do. Creating a sense of community and collaboration comes from allowing team members to examine their capacity to give.&#160;</p><p>Ask the hard questions like: Are they working through personal things at home? This is especially relevant now when people are dealing with mental health and safety concerns.&#160;</p><p>Having an open conversation about availability is what forms a healthy <a href=\"https://www.entrepreneur.com/topic/work-culture\">work culture</a>. Instead of slowly watching employees burnout, talk with them and really listen to their needs. In doing so, you're improving your company's overall health, creativity, and performance. As Branson wisely <a href=\"https://www.virgin.com/disruptors/what-employee-wellbeing-means-me-richard-branson\">emphasizes</a>, you'll establish an environment in which everyone can flourish.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/get-rid-of-your-firms-workaholic-culture-in-3-steps-2020-8'>Business Insider</a></div><div border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=aOcimV18Kuo:JZCr1Ug7Zh0:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=aOcimV18Kuo:JZCr1Ug7Zh0:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/aOcimV18Kuo\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 31 Aug 2020 13:07:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f46c639cd2fec00296a460f?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"4b97f714bd42f3c9f509200da0736e41","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn87@2020_4/2020/08/31/17-21-55-853_b447aec013d19eca.webp","destWidth":1777,"destHeight":1333,"sourceBytes":168028,"destBytes":168028,"author":"insider@insider.com (Aytekin Tank)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f46c690cd2fec00296a4616?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn95@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-22-06-231_407e70aca338f4fc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn51@2020_3/2020/08/31/17-22-14-421_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=aOcimV18Kuo:JZCr1Ug7Zh0:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn55@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-21-57-593_88c8d6d99e2a51d0.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=aOcimV18Kuo:JZCr1Ug7Zh0:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn87@2020_3/2020/08/31/17-22-13-477_c81e6f8dd26596e6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn76@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-22-07-798_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=aOcimV18Kuo:JZCr1Ug7Zh0:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn11@2020_6/2020/08/31/17-22-21-570_65ed297b02d973b3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/aOcimV18Kuo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn59@2020_4/2020/08/31/17-22-08-813_f6e159d31290971c.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598894512878},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","title":"What living on Earth would be like without the moon","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-life-earth-would-change-without-moon-disappeared-2018-3","description":"<div style=\"position:relative; overflow:hidden; padding-bottom:56.25%\">\n<iframe src=\"https://cdn.jwplayer.com/players/u14hK9KI-jZbcmOYf.html\"\nwidth=\"100%\" height=\"100%\" frameborder=\"0\" scrolling=\"auto\" title=\"What living on Earth would be like without the moon\"\nstyle=\"position:absolute;\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n</div><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>Each year, the moon drifts an estimated 1.5 inches further away from Earth.&#160;</li><li>The moon has the largest influence on Earth's tides and without it, high and low tides would shrink by an estimated 75%.</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p><em>Following is a transcript of the video.</em></p><p><strong>Narrator: </strong>Our <a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/20-facts-about-the-moon-2012-12\">moon</a> is on the move. Each year, it drifts an estimated 1.5 inches further away from Earth. And in the process, <a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/earth-stopped-rotating-life-implications-science-physics-2017-2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Earth's rotation</a> is actually slowing down. What if one night, the moon simply disappeared? Would we miss it?</p><p>A full moon is on average 14,000 times brighter than the next brightest night-sky object, <a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/why-nasa-wont-send-humans-to-venus-2017-3\">Venus</a>. So without it, every night would be as dark as a new moon. And star gazing would be spectacular.</p><p>But by the next morning, you'd begin to realize just how important the moon is for life on Earth. To start, between the sun, Earth's rotation, and the moon, the moon has the largest influence on Earth's <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-ocean-tides-work-lunar-gravity-2017-6\">tides</a>.</p><p>Without it, high and low tides would shrink by an estimated 75%. This would jeopardize the lives of many types of crabs, mussels, and sea snails that live in tidal zones and disrupt the diets of larger animals who rely on them for food, threatening entire coastal ecosystems in the process. Within a few decades, we would start to see mass population declines in the sea and on land.</p><p>One of the largest spawning events in the world occurs in the <a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/great-barrier-reef-turning-white-2016-3\">Great Barrier Reef</a>. Each November in the days following the light of a full moon, coral colonies across the reef &#8212; spanning an area larger than the state of New Mexico &#8212; release millions of egg and sperm sacs within nearly minutes of one another. Scientists are certain that the full moon plays a role in the timing, but exactly how remains a mystery.</p><p>On land, animals like these <a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/crabs-migrate-christmas-island-2018-1\">Red Crabs</a> also use lunar cues to reproduce. After living most of their lives in the mountains, millions of adult crabs migrate down to shore. And then, only during the last quarter of the moon, females release their eggs into the sea.</p><p>Now, the moon may not hold as much sway over human reproduction. But without it, something else we care equally about would change &#8212; the weather. Tides and tidal currents help mix cold arctic waters with warmer waters in the tropics. This balances temperatures and stabilizes the climate worldwide. Without the moon, weather forecasts would be practically impossible. The average difference between the hottest and coldest places on Earth could grow to life-threatening extremes.</p><p>But none of this compares to the biggest change that we would have coming over the next millennia. Right now, Earth tilts on its axis at 23.5&#186; mostly due to the moon's gravity. If the moon disappeared, Earth's axis would wobble between anywhere from 10 to 45&#186;.</p><p>Some experts estimate that Jupiter could help keep Earth's tilt from reeling completely out of control. But even just an extra 10&#186; tilt could wreak havoc on the climate and seasons.<br >In the past, Earth's tilt has changed by about 1-2&#186;, which scientists think could have caused <a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/cosmos-explanation-of-earths-ice-ages-2014-5\">Ice Ages</a> in the past. It's hard to know what a 10&#186; or 45&#186; tilt would do but probably nothing good for most life on Earth.</p><p>The moon isn't just imperative for life on Earth today. Experts believe that it may also have played a key role in the formation of life more than 3.5 billion years ago. Turns out, the moon isn't just a beacon of light in the night sky. Its existence is crucial to the delicate balancing act that makes life here possible.</p><p><em>Video courtesy of <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/norazian/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Instagram/@Norazian</a>, <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/faulkner_photography/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Instagram/faulkner_photography</a></em></p><p><em>EDITOR'S NOTE: This video was originally published in March 2018.</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a to repurchase equity interests held by certain minority shareholders of NIO China, and for research and development in autonomous driving technologies, global market development and general corporate purposes,\" it <a href=\"https://ir.nio.com/news-events/news-releases/news-release-details/nio-inc-announces-pricing-offering-88500000-american\">said in a statement</a>.</p><p><em><strong>Read more: these 9 stocks that are poised to continue crushing the market as the 'shared favorites' of Wall Street's biggest investors</a></em></p><p>The secondary offering was larger than expected. skyrocketed.&#160;</p><p>Nio has surged as much as <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/nio-stock\">360% year-to-date through Friday's close</a>.</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> 2020 14:58:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f11aec1f0f4192776696cf2?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"e82f94190ea5f0d9f8b023becdd83d3e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn4@2020_4/2020/08/31/17-21-55-778_cbd48d75ab10ce5a.webp","destWidth":2667,"destHeight":2000,"sourceBytes":206016,"destBytes":206016,"author":"insider@insider.com 01:21:52","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","title":"Billionaire investor Leon Cooperman cheers FANG stocks, says they're 'better than gold'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/fang-stocks-tech-leon-cooperman-better-investment-gold-microsoft-amazon-2020-8","description":"<p><strong><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dc5cb373afd375ba117c045?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Leon Cooperman\" height=\"1250\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jeff Zelevansky/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></strong></p><ul><li><strong>Billionaire investor Leon Cooperman said that FANG stocks are \"better than gold\" during a <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/video/2020/08/31/cnbcs-full-interview-with-billionaire-investor-lee-cooperman.html\">Monday interview with CNBC.</a> </strong></li><li><strong>He also said that he owns <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/googl-stock\">Google</a>, <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/amzn-stock\">Amazon</a>, <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/fb-stock\">Facebook</a>, and <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/msft-stock\">Microsoft</a> but is not adding to positions right now.&#160;</strong></li><li><strong>Cooperman added that today's FANG stocks remind him of the \"nifty fifty\" stocks that led the market in the 1970s.&#160;</strong></li><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/\">Read more on Business Insider</a>.</strong></li></ul><hr ><p>Billionaire investor Leon Cooperman is a big fan of FANG stocks.&#160;</p><p>\"I own <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/googl-stock\">Google</a>, I own <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/amzn-stock\">Amazon</a>, I own <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/msft-stock\">Microsoft</a>, and <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/fb-stock\">Facebook</a>,\" Cooperman <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/video/2020/08/31/cnbcs-full-interview-with-billionaire-investor-lee-cooperman.html\">told CNBC during an interview Monday</a>.&#160; \"They're better than gold.\"&#160;</p><p>Big technology stocks have been at the forefront of the stock market's swift rebound rally from March lows fueled by the coronavirus pandemic. Investors have piled into the stocks and pushed them to record highs as they see technology poised to withstand the pandemic shock and recession.&#160;</p><p>Even though some of the most popular technology stocks are historically expensive, they might still be worth it, according to Cooperman. \"They are not cheap, they are pricey,\" said Cooperman. \"But, they are not pricey relative to interest rates.\"&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-crash-david-rosenberg-dot-com-tech-bubble-distortions-2020-8\" data-analytics-position=\"5\" data-analytics-module=\"\">35-year market vet David Rosenberg warns the stock market's rally features distortions that were glaring during the tech bubble &#8212; and lays out his plausible scenario for a crash</a></em></p><p>He is not adding to his positions of FANG stocks, but is \"sitting with them because these are great companies,\" he said.&#160;</p><p>Cooperman also noted that the FANG stocks remind him of the \"nifty fifty\" stocks that led the market in the 1970s and included companies such as Avon, <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/kodk-stock\">Eastman Kodak</a>, <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/ibm-stock\">IBM</a>, and Sears &#8212; some of which turned out to be disappointing in the long term.&#160;</p><p>Today, it's likely that the same thing will happen with technology stocks, according to Cooperman. \"You identify your 'nifty fifty' of today, and a certain percentage will not perform, they'll be disappointing,\" said Cooperman. \"You take that loss against the ones that work and your expected returns from that portfolio is now particularly impressive.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5dc2ce523afd37129b0f6db2?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"d00bdf70a64bbccabf80a756bd003fa4","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn7@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-22-26-973_4f5fbe3211e35cb3.webp","destWidth":2345,"destHeight":1759,"sourceBytes":156544,"destBytes":156544,"author":"insider@insider.com (Carmen Reinicke)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5dc5cb373afd375ba117c045?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn71@2020_2/2020/08/31/17-22-14-812_9b473a39d7a31920.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn51@2020_3/2020/08/31/17-22-14-421_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=eVhMeVZZ-8E:4LVqTN-SCBE:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn83@2020_5/2020/08/31/17-22-11-739_739f072090bf7419.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=eVhMeVZZ-8E:4LVqTN-SCBE:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn15@2020_3/2020/08/31/17-22-17-227_4c234970999e7aec.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn76@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-22-07-798_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=eVhMeVZZ-8E:4LVqTN-SCBE:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn59@2020_5/2020/08/31/17-22-07-741_57ff47dc379a1a5c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/eVhMeVZZ-8E":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn32@2020_4/2020/08/31/17-22-03-688_f54273934791ff81.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598894512858},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","title":"More US troops say they would vote for Biden than Trump as favorable views of the president fade among those serving in the military, new poll shows","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/poll-more-us-troops-say-they-prefer-biden-to-trump-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f45ad4189aff80028ab7efd?format=jpeg\" alt=\"donald trump\" height=\"2401\" width=\"4803\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>U.S. President Donald Trump talks to reporters while hosting Republican Congressional leaders and members of his cabinet in the Oval Office at the White House July 20, 2020 in Washington, DC. Trump and his guests talked about a proposed new round of financial stimulus to help the economy during the ongoing global coronavirus pandemic.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Doug Mills-Pool/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>More US service members said they would vote for former Vice President Joe Biden than President Donald Trump in a recent <a href=\"https://www.militarytimes.com/news/pentagon-congress/2020/08/31/as-trumps-popularity-slips-in-latest-military-times-poll-more-troops-say-theyll-vote-for-biden/\">survey of more than one thousand active-duty US troops conducted by Military Times</a>.</li><li>The survey also found that unfavorable views of the president are on the rise, jumping from 37% four years ago to 49.9% now.</li><li>The survey also found significant disagreements with the president among US troops over a variety of issues ranging from using active-duty military to quell civil unrest in American cities to the White House's handling of reports that Russia paid militants to kill US troops in Afghanistan.</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>More US service members prefer Democratic nominee Joe Biden to incumbent President Donald Trump, <a href=\"https://www.militarytimes.com/news/pentagon-congress/2020/08/31/as-trumps-popularity-slips-in-latest-military-times-poll-more-troops-say-theyll-vote-for-biden/\">a new Military Times poll reveals</a>.</p><p>A voluntary survey of 1,018 active-duty troops <a href=\"https://www.militarytimes.com/news/pentagon-congress/2020/08/31/as-trumps-popularity-slips-in-latest-military-times-poll-more-troops-say-theyll-vote-for-biden/\">conducted by Military Times</a> in partnership with the Institute for Veterans and Military Families at Syracuse University between July 27 and August 10 found that 43.1% of respondents would vote for Biden while only 37.4% would vote for Trump. The margin of error was, for most of the survey questions, less than 2%.</p><p>For comparison, a 2016 Military Times poll of US service members showed that 40.5% said they would vote for Trump. Only 20.6% of respondents reported they would vote for former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton.</p><p>Trump has repeatedly referred to the armed forces as \"my military\" while referring to top officers as \"my generals,\" and he often boasts about all that he has done for the military, including soaring spending increases aimed at rebuilding a force ground down by the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.</p><p>Still, the view of the president among active-duty US troops is increasingly unfavorable, <a href=\"https://www.militarytimes.com/news/pentagon-congress/2020/08/31/as-trumps-popularity-slips-in-latest-military-times-poll-more-troops-say-theyll-vote-for-biden/\">found the Military Times poll released Monday.</a>.</p><p>Over the past four years, favorable views of Trump among US service members have dropped significantly from 46.1% in 2016 to 37.8% in the most recent survey, with unfavorable views of the president surging from 37% to 49.9%.</p><p>Many who were surveyed disagreed with some of the president's actions and policies.</p><p>For example, while more than half of respondents supported calling in the National Guard to address civil unrest, 74% of the US service members that responded to the poll said that they opposed Trump's proposals to use active-duty US military to quell unrest in American cities, something Trump's own secretary of defense pushed back against.</p><p>In June, a number of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/former-military-leaders-slam-trumps-handling-of-protests-2020-6\">former top US military leaders sharply criticized Trump's militarized handling of the protests</a> in response to concerns about police brutality and racial injustice following the death of George Floyd. The latest Military Times survey revealed more unfavorable views of Trump among officers than enlisted.</p><p>Looking at other important issues, <a href=\"https://www.militarytimes.com/news/pentagon-congress/2020/08/31/as-trumps-popularity-slips-in-latest-military-times-poll-more-troops-say-theyll-vote-for-biden/\">the Military Times poll</a> found that only 17% of those surveyed felt the Trump administration properly addressed reports suggesting that Russia had paid militants in Afghanistan bounties for targeting US troops, and more than half felt that troop levels in Germany, which the White House moved to cut, should be kept at the same level or increased.</p><p>Commenting on the survey results, Peter Feaver, a Duke University political science professor and a former White House adviser to President George W. Bush, <a href=\"https://www.militarytimes.com/news/pentagon-congress/2020/08/31/as-trumps-popularity-slips-in-latest-military-times-poll-more-troops-say-theyll-vote-for-biden/\">told Military Times</a> that the recent poll results \"do not necessarily show that troops are beginning to think more like Democrats, but instead that they aren't thinking like Trump Republicans.\"</p><p>\"The bottom line,\" he said, \"is that in 2020, Trump can't be claiming to have overwhelming support in the military.\"</p><p>Polls like the recent Military Times survey are representative of ony one moment in time and not necessarily the entire force. Views of the candidates within the military have the potential to change between now and the election.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a alt=\"Global Consumer Interest in Retail Technology Innovatiosn\" height=\"375\" width=\"650\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Business Insider Intelligence</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul><li><strong>Shop Anywhere.&#160;</strong>Mastercard partnered with Accel Robotics to develop AI and computer vision technology that will allow customers to shop and pay without waits or checkout lines, creating an experience similar to autonomous checkout. It'll partner with Circle K, Delaware North, and one Dunkin' location to test the technology beginning in October.</li><li><strong>AI Powered Drive Through.&#160;</strong>The solution enables restaurants to offer customers personalized or dynamic menus on their mobile devices, based on store preferences, historical ordering trends, or other inputs. It can eliminate employee-led ordering and speed up wait times, and will be piloted at White Castle and other undisclosed quick-service chains this fall.</li></ul><p>The new solutions might make Mastercard an attractive partner as the pandemic changes retail preferences and habits.Though in-store shopping is beginning to&#160;<a href=\"https://e.businessinsider.com/click/21349219.\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https://www.google.com/url?q=https://e.businessinsider.com/click/21349219.&source=gmail&ust=1598973129581000&usg=AFQjCNELxRvD1_G6TzvL2Fh1kNcU8Tg2mAh1kNcU8Tg2mA\">rebound</a>&#160;from lows in April, customers remain wary: 32% of shoppers feel unsafe at shopping malls, 20% at warehouse clubs, and 18% at big box stores, per&#160;<a href=\"https://e.businessinsider.com/click/21349219.3/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuYnVzaW5lc3N3aXJlLmNvbS9uZXdzL2hvbWUvMjAyMDA3MjgwMDU3MzcvZW4vQ29uc3VtZXJzLUFmcmFpZC1TaG9wLUluLVN0b3JlLVJldGFpbGVycy0lRTIlODAlOUNNYXNrLVVwJUUyJTgwJTlE/5adde55340f86675182a51c9B69e4556b\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https://www.google.com/url?q=https://e.businessinsider.com/click/21349219.3/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuYnVzaW5lc3N3aXJlLmNvbS9uZXdzL2hvbWUvMjAyMDA3MjgwMDU3MzcvZW4vQ29uc3VtZXJzLUFmcmFpZC1TaG9wLUluLVN0b3JlLVJldGFpbGVycy0lRTIlODAlOUNNYXNrLVVwJUUyJTgwJTlE/5adde55340f86675182a51c9B69e4556b&source=gmail&ust=1598973129581000&usg=AFQjCNFwIzIBdDQ2Zq48X7qEA3ryx-RI7AqEA3ryx-RI7A\">First Insight</a>. Mastercard's solutions could make customers more comfortable by speeding up processes, allowing retailers to reduce capacity, and decreasing physical contact. And they might be popular as customers, who were already&#160;<a href=\"https://e.businessinsider.com/click/21349219.3/aHR0cHM6Ly9pbnRlbGxpZ2VuY2UuYnVzaW5lc3NpbnNpZGVyLmNvbS9wb3N0L2NvbnN1bWVycy13b3JsZHdpZGUtYXJlLWludGVyZXN0ZWQtaW4tcmV0YWlsLXRlY2hub2xvZ3ktaW5ub3ZhdGlvbi1oZXJlcy13aGF0LXByb3ZpZGVycy1zaG91bGQtZm9jdXMtb24tYXMtdGhleS1kZXZlbG9wLXByb2R1Y3RzLTIwMjAtMi0xMw/5adde55340f86675182a51c9Bd83dc5de\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https://www.google.com/url?q=https://e.businessinsider.com/click/21349219.3/aHR0cHM6Ly9pbnRlbGxpZ2VuY2UuYnVzaW5lc3NpbnNpZGVyLmNvbS9wb3N0L2NvbnN1bWVycy13b3JsZHdpZGUtYXJlLWludGVyZXN0ZWQtaW4tcmV0YWlsLXRlY2hub2xvZ3ktaW5ub3ZhdGlvbi1oZXJlcy13aGF0LXByb3ZpZGVycy1zaG91bGQtZm9jdXMtb24tYXMtdGhleS1kZXZlbG9wLXByb2R1Y3RzLTIwMjAtMi0xMw/5adde55340f86675182a51c9Bd83dc5de&source=gmail&ust=1598973129581000&usg=AFQjCNEGX4gAwj81vJIbwCNK1s7hU_ET3ANK1s7hU_ET3A\">interested</a>&#160;in retail technology innovations,&#160;<a href=\"https://e.businessinsider.com/click/21349219.3/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cucHJ3ZWIuY29tL3JlbGVhc2VzL3Vfc19zaG9wcGVyc19hcmVfaW5jcmVhc2luZ2x5X3Nob3BwaW5nX29uX21vYmlsZV9kZXZpY2VzL3Byd2ViMTczNTI5NDYuaHRt/5adde55340f86675182a51c9Bdd8c7b1f\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https://www.google.com/url?q=https://e.businessinsider.com/click/21349219.3/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cucHJ3ZWIuY29tL3JlbGVhc2VzL3Vfc19zaG9wcGVyc19hcmVfaW5jcmVhc2luZ2x5X3Nob3BwaW5nX29uX21vYmlsZV9kZXZpY2VzL3Byd2ViMTczNTI5NDYuaHRt/5adde55340f86675182a51c9Bdd8c7b1f&source=gmail&ust=1598973129581000&usg=AFQjCNFH_KD1wGq6OJmtXBHalhxTGIHdtwHalhxTGIHdtw\">warm</a>&#160;to mobile shopping &#8212; in turn driving a slew of new merchant partners to Mastercard and boosting its presence in the space.</p><p><strong><em>Want to read more stories like this one? Here's how you can gain access:</em></strong></p><ol><li>Join other Insider Intelligence clients who receive this Briefing, along with other Payments &#38; Commerce forecasts, briefings, charts, and
