August 24, 2010 in Chicago, Illinois.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Scott Olson/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>You don't always have to build something from scratch if there's a perfectly good solution already available. For example, owning a franchise is one way that many Ivy League grads put their business acumen to work. Franchise empires require time, research, and a healthy amount of cash up-front, but the model can be a sustainable source of income for entrepreneurs.</p><p>We got the scoop on how a group of Harvard grads created fast food empires through franchising.&#160;</p><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-harvard-business-school-ivy-league-grads-fast-food-franchise-empires\">Here's how they did it.</a></strong></p><h1><strong>Welcome to Success Insider, our regular newsletter for getting things done.&#160;</strong></h1><p>This week, we have Instagram tips for small business owners, financial advice from early retirees, insights from the CEO of Trivago, and more.&#160;</p><section><h2>Almost half of entrepreneurs struggle with mental health. 8 founders and investors explain how they cope with isolation and intense pressure.</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f171348988ee353004fc902?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Elon Musk\" height=\"1886\" width=\"2514\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Elon Musk.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mike Blake/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></section><p>The rollercoaster nature of entrepreneurship, with its mercurial highs and lows, can strain the mental health of founders and small-business owners, which contributes to the field's high rates of depression and mental illness. Business Insider spoke to eight founders to find out how they manage their mental health.</p><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/founders-explain-mental-health-challenges-of-entrepreneurship-strategies-dealing-with-depression\">Read more here.</a></strong></p><section><h2>Small business founders share 4 strategies they used to crack Instagram and gain a new wave of customers during the pandemic</h2></section><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f437cf542f43f001ddfe8d3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Ade and Antonia Ogunsola of Okiki Skincare\" height=\"1836\" width=\"2448\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Ade (L) and Antonia Ogunsola of Okiki Skincare.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Okiki Skincare</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The COVID-19 pandemic has hammered small businesses, and many have turned to Instagram to connect with their ever-loyal customers. We spoke to small business founders who are successful on the platform during lockdown. They shared their top strategies for gaining a new wave of customers.</p><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/instagram-for-small-businesses-successful-founders-share-top-tips-2020-8\">Read more here.</a></strong></p><section><h1>A therapy startup set to launch in person in March pivoted online in one week and went on to land $6 million in funding, and now it's looking to reinvent mental-health care as people grapple with the effects of the pandemic</h1><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f451b1289aff80028ab7b70?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Ariela Safira\" height=\"1503\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Ariela Safira.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Ariela Safira</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>When Ariela Safira's plans to launch Real, a therapy startup, were disrupted by the pandemic, her team had to quickly pivot to digital. Now, she's raised $6 million in funding from Forerunner Ventures, Female Founders Fund, and Gwyneth Paltrow, and shares how Real's been tailoring their products to match what their customers want today.</p><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-therapy-startup-real-ceo-pivoted-online-mental-healthcare-2020-8\">Read more here.</a></strong></p><section><h2>Why the key to career success is, surprisingly, to make yourself dispensable to your company, according to the CEO of travel giant Trivago</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f46763689aff80028ab8070?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Trivago&#39;s CEO Axel Hefer.\" height=\"3599\" width=\"4799\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Trivago CEO Axel Hefer.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Trivago</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>When COVID-19 hit Europe in January, Axel Hefer was appointed Trivago's CEO, having been managing director and chief financial officer for the travel comparison firm for the previous four years. He shares his five tips for career success.</p><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/get-promoted-at-work-career-tips-trivago-ceo-2020-8\">Read more here.</a></strong></p><section><h2>Self-made millionaires who retired in their 30s didn't factor a pandemic into their financial planning. Here's what they're doing with their money now.</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e7e602f1378e3236761b7ee?format=jpeg\" alt=\"early retiree\" height=\"1334\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Soonthorn Kittikarnjanakorn/EyeEm</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The coronavirus pandemic has changed the calculus for many retirees, but what about the self-made millionaire early retirees who largely rely on investments to fund their lifestyle? They told Business Insider they're not worried about their money, but some have changed things up in big ways.</p><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-self-made-millionaire-early-retirees-prepared-for-a-recession-2020-3\">Here's why.</a></strong></p><section><h2>How an entrepreneur bootstrapped a syrup business from her mother's attic that sold out on Amazon in an hour and is now on the shelves of over 8,000 retailers</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f3bf7e3a3eafa001de06bba?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Michele Hoskins\" height=\"720\" width=\"960\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Michele Hoskins.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy of Michele Hoskins</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>When Michele Hoskins started Michele Foods, the young entrepreneur was a newly divorced teacher with three children and no source of investor capital. Three decades later, Hoskins has grown her syrup into a business with products in more than 8,000 stores across the country &#8211; and the brand only gained popularity when PepsiCo's Aunt Jemima was pulled off shelves.&#160;</p><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/bootstrap-maple-syrup-business-michele-foods-2020-8\">Here's how she did it.</a></strong></p><section><h2>The founder of the most popular kombucha brand in America explains how the company recovered from a dramatic drop in sales during the pandemic</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f3ed08b9f3aff00288eee30?format=jpeg\" alt=\"GT Dave, founder of GT&#39;s Living Foods\" height=\"1648\" width=\"2198\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>GT Dave is the founder of GT&#39;s Living Foods.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy of GT&#39;s Living Foods</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></section><p>GT Dave started his kombucha company as a teen in 1995, home-brewing in his parents' kitchen and pitching his way into health and grocery stores. Decades later, the company has recovered from plummeting sales during the pandemic and started a home delivery service to meet demand for its popular tea drink.</p><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/kombucha-founder-gt-daves-sales-slump-recovery-direct-consumer-2020-8\">Read more here.</a></strong></p><h2>Leaders from companies like PwC and FlexJobs share their best advice for creating an inclusive company culture now that working from home is extended</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f1863921918243a402aabb3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Remote work coronavirus\" height=\"1363\" width=\"1817\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A video producer works from his at-home studio to conduct remote interviews with talent on April 19, 2020 in Franklin Square, New York.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Eric Stringer/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>It can be hard to maintain a positive company culture when everyone's working remotely.&#160;Here's what execs at companies like PwC and FlexJobs say you should do to build an inclusive working environment.&#160;</p><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/work-from-home-jobs-company-culture-coronavirus-pandemic-pwc-flexjobs-2020-8\">Read more here.</a></strong></p></section></section></section></section><div border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=zkYEciQgLZc:K0WPjrnXS9I:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=zkYEciQgLZc:K0WPjrnXS9I:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=zkYEciQgLZc:K0WPjrnXS9I:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=zkYEciQgLZc:K0WPjrnXS9I:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/zkYEciQgLZc\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 31 Aug 2020 16:03:54 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5e5d2226fee23d03f44f001a?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"734fa92fdecf478a7a882ee85c27723c","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn79@2020_5/2020/08/31/17-21-53-571_79091e775ac443df.webp","destWidth":4352,"destHeight":3264,"sourceBytes":959216,"destBytes":959216,"author":"insider@insider.com (Business Insider)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5e5d2226fee23d03f44f001a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn79@2020_5/2020/08/31/17-21-53-571_79091e775ac443df.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f171348988ee353004fc902?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn64@2020_6/2020/08/31/17-22-19-598_b7e84180079b7d0a.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f437cf542f43f001ddfe8d3?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn91@2020_6/2020/08/31/17-22-16-459_c1257987756ba0d4.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f451b1289aff80028ab7b70?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn16@2020_3/2020/08/31/17-21-58-318_d4532ab79e5a9a33.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f46763689aff80028ab8070?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn39@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-22-07-525_62ac3aa5e374faa9.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e7e602f1378e3236761b7ee?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn64@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-22-07-598_a985d0cb9d2c4e0f.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f3bf7e3a3eafa001de06bba?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn32@2020_3/2020/08/31/17-22-19-086_36519c7f80d5cb69.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f3ed08b9f3aff00288eee30?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn91@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-21-56-920_a0b9e4fee588dd14.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f1863921918243a402aabb3?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn83@2020_3/2020/08/31/17-22-13-392_605ae98d96ed6ef5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn51@2020_3/2020/08/31/17-22-14-421_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=zkYEciQgLZc:K0WPjrnXS9I:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn68@2020_5/2020/08/31/17-22-02-108_a8160233e681724a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=zkYEciQgLZc:K0WPjrnXS9I:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn20@2020_2/2020/08/31/17-21-58-323_eba3cf3a04fe16f0.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn76@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-22-07-798_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=zkYEciQgLZc:K0WPjrnXS9I:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn31@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-22-21-571_68bb149505b9ae3f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/zkYEciQgLZc":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn47@2020_4/2020/08/31/17-22-14-296_cc0dfd84b7314839.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598894512908},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","title":"I was one of the first female fighter helicopter pilots in the US Army. Here's the technique I used to stay motivated while waiting for an assignment.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-one-of-armys-first-female-apache-pilots-stayed-motivated-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4954127ffa48002894cef2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"AH-64 Apache helicopters Navy Lewis B. Puller\" height=\"933\" width=\"1244\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>AH-64 Apache helicopters operate with the expeditionary landing base ship USS Lewis B. Puller during a joint naval and air integration operation in the Persian Gulf, March 27, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">US Army/Spc. Cody Rich</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>Shannon Huffman Polson is one of the first female Apache helicopter pilots in the Army; in addition to her military service, she spent five years leading and managing in the corporate sector at Guidant and Microsoft.&#160;</li><li>The following is an excerpt from her new book, \"<a href=\"https://store.hbr.org/product/the-grit-factor-courage-resilience-and-leadership-in-the-most-male-dominated-organization-in-the-world/10260\">The Grit Factor: Courage, Resilience and Leadership in the Most Male Dominated Organization in the World</a>.\"</li><li>In it, she describes a technique called the Five Whys, which was developed by Taiichi Ohno, the founder of the Toyota Production System.</li><li>Essentially, you ask yourself why you do what you do five times, which helps you determine your core purpose.</li><li>For Polson, this helped her connect to the meaning of wanting to serve &#8212; even when times were hard or discouraging.</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>Friedrich Nietzsche once said that \"he who has a why can endure any how.\" Your purpose is your \"why.\" In my experience, however, asking why often doesn't go far enough. Sometimes doing so only scratches the surface, revealing what Aaron Hurst calls the cause as opposed to the purpose. To dig deeper, deep enough to discover your core purpose, to connect your intellectual sense of purpose with your core purpose, ask yourself why you do what you do not once but five times. Yes, five.</p><p>I was first introduced to the Five Whys as a technique developed by Taiichi Ohno, the founder of the Toyota Production System. Ohno used the Five Whys as the technique to drill down into deficiencies, to permit a deeper look into problems. This practice of asking the Five Whys became standard at Toyota and later became part of the Six Sigma training program. By the repetition of inquiry into a given defect, Toyota found itself better able to discern the root causes of failures and avoid creating further problems brought on by quick, surface-level analyses.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4951367ffa48002894ceca?format=jpeg\" alt=\"PoslonShannon_AltCrop\" height=\"468\" width=\"625\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Shannon Huffman Polson.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy of Shannon Huffman Polson</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>How does a manufacturing tactic relate to purpose? By its insistence on getting to root cause, or what I call core purpose.</p><p>Your purpose addresses the task at hand. It considers what you are doing now, and why you're doing it. Your <em>core </em>purpose goes deeper. Your core purpose is what drives you today and every day. It is foundational to who you are, what makes you unique, what forms the core of your being. Your story informs your core purpose, and your core purpose informs the future of your story. In the face of so many competing distractions, discerning core purpose takes quiet and focused attention.</p><p>In the writing workshops I lead, I use an exercise to introduce the concept of the long, hard look &#8212; a necessary step to get to the core truths or meaning the writers are seeking to convey, even if they think they already know. I ask participants to turn toward someone they don't know, and to look directly into their eyes without looking away for a full minute (sometimes two). By the end of the exercise, some participants are squirming, some trying not to laugh, others concentrating hard on pushing through the discomfort. The process is awkward at best, but it can make us realize that the hard look may require us to get uncomfortable.</p><p>Most of us aren't willing to face the places in ourselves that might be challenging, pieces of ourselves that we have worked to ignore for any number of reasons. But in writing, as in leadership (and in all of life), we often have to push ourselves to delve deeper than daily life allows in order to find the meaning hidden beneath the surface.</p><p>The Five Whys is similar, forcing the long, hard look, beyond and beneath \"cause\" and even \"purpose\" in a specific situation, to discover core purpose. By continuing your investigation into purpose until you've drilled down five layers, you'll have moved past the superficial, finding the bedrock of what matters most to you.</p><h2>Digging into my core purpose</h2><p>When I reported for duty to Fort Bragg, North Carolina, I was twenty-three, newly graduated from Officer Basic Course, the Initial Entry Rotary Wing course, and the Apache attack- helicopter transition course. I was ready to fly and excited to lead my first platoon.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f49516e7ffa48002894cecc?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Polson10260_300dpi\" height=\"3010\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Grit Factor: Courage, Resilience, and Leadership in the Most Male-Dominated Organization in the World.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Harvard Business Review Press</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Arriving at Fort Bragg, I was the first woman assigned to the regiment, the only woman out of 120 combat pilots. I was assigned not to the platoon I had hoped for, but instead to serve as the assistant to the assistant S-3 operations officer, of 3rd Battalion, 229th Attack Aviation. I worked for a captain who assigned me to type up presentations and appendixes to operations orders. It was not without value, but it was a long way from where I thought I would have been.</p><p>The work soon became deadening, and my frustration heightened when I learned secondhand what a lieutenant in our sister battalion was saying &#8212; that I hadn't been assigned a platoon because I wasn't up for it. Never mind that I knew the other lieutenant to be solidly mediocre in every sense. I talked to the captain I was working for, asking him when a platoon might be possible. He looked up from his desk impatiently.</p><p>\"Lieutenant,\" he said, \"the Army doesn't owe you anything.\"</p><p>I realized with a pang of despair that just because I had been trained didn't mean I would get the chance I had hoped for to be an aviation leader.</p><p>Even so, I remembered the adage passed down by my dad, who had learned it from his parents, who came from farm country in Kansas: if you're scrubbing toilets for twenty-five cents, you'd better earn every penny of that doing the best job you can. I knew that regardless of my disappointment, I had to excel at what I was doing and fight against my frustration. In order to do that, I had to find a way to connect to my core purpose &#8212; and I did it by asking the Five Whys.</p><p>When I first asked myself why I was where I was, why I was doing what I was doing, I started with:</p><p>\"I'm here to fly and fight in the Apache helicopter and be an Army aviation leader.\"</p><p>That might motivate me temporarily, but it was easy to get stuck in the frustration of what I was not doing: flying and fighting in the Apache helicopter. Becoming an aviation leader may have been my purpose (though from Aaron Hurst's perspective, that job-related answer reflected more of a cause than a purpose), but I was not yet presented with the opportunity to do so, and I had little control over the decisions made. Without being able to change my circumstance, the only option I had available to keep me motivated in my work was connecting to my core purpose. I kept asking the question.</p><p>Why did I want to fly and fight in the Apache helicopter and be an aviation leader?</p><ul><li>Because I'm trained to do so. &#8211; Why?</li><li>Because I earned and requested the training. &#8211; Why?</li><li>Because I wanted to serve my country.</li></ul><p>That was a pretty good place to land, but given that I had signed up to join the Army, it was also a little bit too obvious. I forced myself to ask one more time: &#8211; Why?</p><p>&#8226; Because I wanted to serve.</p><p>Boom! That was it.</p><p>I'd grown up in a patriotic family of Midwestern origin. But more important, I had grown up in a family for which faith and the idea of service were important. As a child, I visited retirement homes with my mother, made sandwiches with our youth group for those who didn't have enough to eat, and drove with my father to deliver food to families who needed it on a Christmas Eve.</p><p>I once asked my father, who was newly surprised by a divorce and exhausted from work, why it was that he continued to volunteer so much, serving on boards and on the vestry at church while he worked so many hours. Even as a young teenager, I could see the toll the deep fatigue was taking on him.</p><p>He responded by quoting those words from the Gospel of Luke that President Kennedy had borrowed as well: \"For those to whom much is given, much is expected.\"</p><p>Growing up with both the demonstration of and espousal of service was a key piece of my makeup, and connecting with this value was important to staying strong and motivated in a job that I saw as discouraging, as possibly even unfair, and, in fleeting moments that seemed to be increasing in frequency, as deadening. By connecting to my core purpose, I could see that I was still serving. This validated the work I was doing and empowered me to act from a place of strength. I may not have been leading a flight platoon yet, but by connecting to my core purpose, I continued to see even the menial tasks as an opportunity to serve, full stop.</p><p>Understanding that my core purpose is to serve undergirds all of my subsequent work, informs much of how I spend my time out of uniform, and even more fundamentally, articulates a value that is a significant part of what makes me who I am. It sustains me when times are hard and gives me direction when I feel the need to course-correct. Drilling down to core purpose is fundamental to accessing and developing grit.</p><p><em>Reprinted by permission of Harvard Business Review Press. Adapted from&#160;The Grit Factor: Courage, Resilience and Leadership in the Most Male Dominated Organization in the World&#160;by Shannon Huffman Polson. Copyright 2020 Shannon Huffman Polson.&#160;Copyright 2020 Harvard Business School Publishing Corporation. All right reserved.</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 01:21:52","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","title":"Aimmune Therapeutics soars 172% after Nestle agrees to acquire the peanut allergy treatment company for $2.6 billion","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/aimmune-therapeutics-stock-price-nestle-acquire-peanut-allergy-company-billions-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d1c817ffa48002894d23a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"trader cheering\" height=\"1500\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Spencer Platt/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul><li><strong>Aimmune Therapeutics soared 172% on Monday after Nestle Health Science agreed to acquire the company for $34.50 per share, or $2.6 billion.</strong></li><li><strong>Aimmune developed a treatment for peanut allergies, Palforzia, which was approved by the FDA in January of this year.</strong></li><li><strong>But the COVID-19 pandemic derailed Aimmune's Palforzia launch plans, leading to a substantial decline in its stock price.</strong></li><li><strong>Prior to today's acquisition, Nestle held a 25.6% stake in Aimmune after a 2016 investment.</strong></li><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestmp;utm_medium=ingest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</strong></li></ul><hr ><p><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/aimt-stock\">Aimmune Therapeutics</a>, a biotechnology company that developed a treatment for peanut allergies, soared 172% on Monday after Nestle Health Science, a division of Nestle, <a href=\"https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2020/08/31/2085837/0/en/Nestl%C3%A9-to-acquire-Aimmune-Therapeutics.html\">agreed to acquire the company</a> for $2.6 billion.</p><p>In January, <a href=\"https://ir.aimmune.com/news-releases/news-release-details/fda-approves-aimmunes-palforziatm-first-treatment-peanut-allergy\">the FDA approved Palforzia</a> as the first treatment ever for peanut allergies. But the COVID-19 pandemic <a href=\"https://ir.aimmune.com/news-releases/news-release-details/aimmune-therapeutics-announces-first-quarter-2020-financial\">delayed Aimmune's commercialization plans</a> for the drug, resulting in a stock price decline of as much as 72% over the ensuing months.</p><p>Palforzia is intended for children aged 4 to 17 years old, and is used to help reduce the frequency and severity of an allergic reaction to peanuts, including anaphylaxis, according to Aimmune. The drug is in pill form and is taken orally.</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong>&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-crash-david-morgan-report-expert-warns-likely-meltdown-2020-8?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestm=ingest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">'Basically one mass manipulation': A market expert unloads on the central bank-driven 'failure' of the modern financial system - and says another stock meltdown is likely coming</a></em></p><p>Nestle already owned a 25.6% stake in the healthcare company. Shortly after the approval of the peanut allergy treatment in January, <a href=\"https://ir.aimmune.com/news-releases/news-release-details/aimmune-therapeutics-announces-additional-200-million-equity\">Nestle announced a $200 million</a> follow-on investment in the company. Nestle had originally invested in Aimmune in 2016.</p><p>Nestle expects the acquisition to be accretive to its organic growth in 2021, and accretive to cash earnings by 2022 or 2023, the company said.&#160;</p><p>Nestle will launch a tender offer to acquire all shares it doesn't already own for $34.50, representing a 174% premium to Aimmune's Friday closing price of $12.60, and a total enterprise value of $2.6 billion.</p><p>Nestle will finance the acquisition with cash on hand and expects the transaction to close in the fourth quarter of 2020.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d28f560bf1f00280797dc?format=jpeg\" alt=\"aimt chart.JPG\" height=\"642\" width=\"851\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Markets Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 01:21:52","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","title":"TikTok has reportedly chosen a buyer and could announce a deal to sell its US business as early as tomorrow","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/tiktok-has-chosen-buyer-could-announce-deal-tuesday-report-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f219f5528ea712c026a9988?format=jpeg\" alt=\"tiktok logo\" height=\"1333\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jakub Porzycki/NurPhoto via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>TikTok has found a buyer for its US operations and could announce the deal as early as Tuesday, <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/08/31/tiktok-deal-to-sell-us-business-could-be-announced-as-soon-as-tomorrow.html\">CNBC reported</a>, citing sources familiar with the matter.</li><li>TikTok's Chinese parent company, ByteDance, has a matter of weeks to sell its US business before a Trump executive order banning the app goes into effect.</li><li>The company is weighing a joint bid from Microsoft and Walmart, as well as an offer from Oracle, among others.</li><li>Former CEO Kevin Mayer said a deal was close when he resigned last week, telling employees to expect \"a resolution very soon.\"</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>TikTok has reportedly decided on a company to buy its US, New Zealand, and Australian businesses and could make an announcement regarding the sale this week.</p><p>CNBC <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/08/31/tiktok-deal-to-sell-us-business-could-be-announced-as-soon-as-tomorrow.html\">reported</a> that the announcement could come as early as Tuesday, citing sources familiar with the matter.</p><p>The company has to finalize the sale in a matter of weeks to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tiktok-sale-disrupted-china-rules-give-self-veto-2020-8\">avoid a ban</a> on its operations ordered by President Donald Trump. China further complicated that timeline on Friday, when it <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tiktok-sale-disrupted-china-rules-give-self-veto-2020-8\">announced new rules</a> that could give the Chinese government veto power over a potential sale.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/microsoft-tiktok-acquisition-trump-cfius-faq-2020-8\">Analysts see a joint bid from Microsoft and Walmart</a> as the strongest offer to buy TikTok, which is also <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/experts-on-oracle-buying-tiktok-reasons-motivation-2020-8\">weighing</a> an offer from Oracle. A <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tiktok-acquisition-potential-buyers-us-operations-investors-microsoft-walmart-oracle-2020-8\">slew of other potential buyers</a> have been rumored in recent weeks, including Netflix, Apple, and Alphabet. Analysts <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/08/27/tiktok-likely-to-announce-sale-us-operations-in-the-coming-days.html\">expect</a> the sale price to be around $20 billion to $30 billion.</p><p>Former CEO Kevin Mayer signaled that a deal could be imminent when he <a href=\"https://edition.cnn.com/2020/08/27/tech/tiktok-kevin-mayer-quits-hnk-intl/index.html\">resigned from the company</a> last week. In his resignation letter, Mayer told employees to anticipate \"a resolution very soon.\"</p><p>A TikTok spokesperson declined to comment.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on 2020 13:49:46 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f4cf8a760bf1f00280796d7?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"5ccfa7aac19475065ff7f627eccb74ee","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn35@2020_5/2020/08/31/17-21-55-751_97e67fe4b22cd227.webp","destWidth":1778,"destHeight":1333,"sourceBytes":22844,"destBytes":22844,"author":"aholmes@businessinsider.com (Aaron Holmes)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f219f5528ea712c026a9988?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn44@2020_6/2020/08/31/17-22-07-410_412e0a261e855002.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn51@2020_3/2020/08/31/17-22-14-421_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Baieqc-eu8k:FqTLdCALFBk:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn63@2020_2/2020/08/31/17-22-11-561_ef4500bcda848ed5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Baieqc-eu8k:FqTLdCALFBk:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn44@2020_3/2020/08/31/17-21-59-825_80f771579c9d2027.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn76@2020_1/2020/08/31/17-22-07-798_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Baieqc-eu8k:FqTLdCALFBk:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn43@2020_2/2020/08/31/17-22-21-569_7d147f38cebbe68e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/Baieqc-eu8k":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn99@2020_6/2020/08/31/17-22-08-206_1f4ab3e7ee2e5b60.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598894512868},{"createdTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","updatedTime":"2020-09-01 01:21:52","title":"Robinhood under investigation by SEC, FINRA for handling of day-long March outage, report says","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/robinhood-sec-finra-investigation-march-trading-service-outage-stock-brokerage-2020-8","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4cf7e560bf1f00280796ca?format=jpeg\" alt=\"robinhood\" height=\"749\" width=\"1500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Robinhood</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul><li><strong>The Securities and Exchange Commission and Financial Industry Regulatory Authority are investigating Robinhood and its handling of an early March service outage, <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-08-31/robinhood-s-rise-brings-dark-side-of-irate-traders-u-s-probes?srnd=premium&sref=LspfQlRvQlRv\">Bloomberg</a> reported Monday.</strong></li><li><strong>The brokerage made headlines after its <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/robinhood-outage-app-back-up-after-glitch-stock-market-rebound-2020-3-1028959673\">trading platform shut down</a> for the entirety of March 2 and some of March 3, leaving investors unable to cash in on a market upswing.</strong></li><li><strong>The regulatory bodies are particularly interested in Robinhood's lack of customer response during the outage, according to Bloomberg. When the brokerage's help center also shut down, customers flooded the SEC with complaints.</strong></li><li><strong>Regulators have privately said they've felt like Robinhood's secondary customer support outlet, sources told Bloomberg.</strong></li><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestutm_source=msn.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_content=msn-slideshow&utm_campaign=bodyurl?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestts&#38;utm_medium=ingest\">Visit the Business Insider homepage for more stories</a>.</strong></li></ul><hr ><p>Robinhood is under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority over its handling of a March outage, <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-08-31/robinhood-s-rise-brings-dark-side-of-irate-traders-u-s-probes?srnd=premium&sref=LspfQlRvQlRv\">Bloomberg</a> reported Monday.</p><p>The discount brokerage caught flak in early March after its <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/robinhood-outage-app-back-up-after-glitch-stock-market-rebound-2020-3-1028959673\">trading service shut down</a> for more than an entire trading day. Investors were unable to gain access to the company's help center, website, or mobile application.&#160;</p><p>The outage kept clients from securing profits on March 2 as coronavirus-linked volatility pushed stocks higher. The <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/index/s&p_500?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestm=ingest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">S&#38;P 500</a> closed up 4.6% that day, while the <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/index/dow_jones?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestgest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Dow Jones industrial average</a> gained nearly 1,300 points, or about 5.1%.</p><p>Robinhood's app faced downtime and slowed performance <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/robinhood-trading-downtime-outage-second-day-backlash-2020-3\">the following day</a>, though not through the entire trading session.</p><p>The investigations arrive as Robinhood transitions from a brokerage-industry upstart to a leading player. The company added more than 3 million accounts as of May, half of which belonged to first-time investors. Robinhood's daily average trades in June <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/robinhood-june-darts-beat-td-ameritrade-schwab-amid-market-volatility-2020-8-1029488598\">reached 4.31 million</a> and beat legacy firms including TD Ameritrade, Charles Schwab, and E-Trade. The rapid growth helped boost Robinhood's total valuation to <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/robinhood-closes-200-million-series-g-funding-round-valuation-billions-2020-8-1029509874\">$11.2 billion</a>&#160;as of mid-August.&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-crash-david-rosenberg-dot-com-tech-bubble-distortions-2020-8\" data-analytics-position=\"5\" data-analytics-module=\"\">35-year market vet David Rosenberg warns the stock market's rally features distortions that were glaring during the tech bubble &#8212; and lays out his plausible scenario for a crash</a></em></p><p>Yet the company's ascension in recent months has also led to increased scrutiny from regulatory bodies. The SEC and FINRA are particularly interested in Robinhood's lack of a timely response to customers affected by the March outages, sources familiar with the probes told Bloomberg.</p><p>Robinhood cited infrastructure \"instability\" for March's system failure and noted that funds and personal information were safe throughout the outage.</p><p>\"When it comes to your money, issues like this are not acceptable. We realize we let you down, and our team is committed to improving your experience,\" Robinhood wrote in an email the day after the March 2 issue.</p><p>The company did not immediately reply to a request for comment.</p><p>The brokerage's setbacks have also driven a great deal of investors' ire to regulatory agencies. Since Robinhood's outages left customers without access to its helpline, clients frequently banded together to flood government offices with complaints.</p><p>Federal Trade Commission comments obtained by Bloomberg show the agency receiving 473 reports on Robinhood from January to mid-July. By comparison, the FTC received 126 reports for Charles Schwab, 111 for E-Trade, and 69 for Fidelity over the same period.</p><p>Regulators have privately said they feel they've become Robinhood's secondary customer service outlet, sources familiar with the talks told Bloomberg.</p><p>Robinhood seems to have heard such complaints. The company plans to hire hundreds more customer service representatives and has already sped up response times and bolstered its trading platform, according to an August 11 <a href=\"https://blog.robinhood.com\">blog post</a>.&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Now read more markets coverage from Markets Insider and Business Insider:</strong></em></p><p><em><strong><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/bill-ackman-child-investing-letter-accounts-economic-wealth-inequality-capitalism-2020-8-1029548114\" data-analytics-position=\"1\" data-analytics-module=\"\">Billionaire Bill Ackman says mandatory investing accounts for every US child could combat wealth inequality</a></strong></em></p><p><em><strong><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/stock-market-outlook-4-reasons-corporate-profits-resilient-coronavirus-recession-2020-8-1029546200\" data-analytics-position=\"2\" data-analytics-module=\"\">A Wall Street chief strategist details 4 reasons why big-company profits have been remarkably resilient during the pandemic &#8212; and explains how that's helped the red-hot stock rally</a></strong></em></p><p><em><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-picks-to-buy-hedge-mutual-funds-market-favorites-goldman-2020-8\" data-analytics-position=\"4\" data-analytics-module=\"\">GOLDMAN SACHS: Buy these 9 stocks that are poised to continue crushing the market as the 'shared favorites' of Wall Street's biggest investors</a></strong></em></p><div
